Authors: Oechel, WC; Vourlitis, GL; Hastings, SJ; Ault, RP; Bryant, P
Title: The effects of water table manipulation and elevated temperature on the net CO2 flux of wet sedge tundra ecosystems
StressorOneNote: Surface temperatures of plots exposed to elevated temperature were increased on average 0.5 °C. Soil surface temperature was elevated using open-top cone-chambers, which were fit over each randomly assigned chamber base. The cones had inwardly inclined sides and an open-top diameter of 1.02 m, and are made of 2 mm thick Lexan Plexiglas which transmits 90% of visible wavelengths and ≈ 5% of infra-red wavelengths.
StressorTwoNote: Water table depth of drained plots was maintained on average 7 cm lower than the ambient water table. Drained plots 0.5 m2 in area were enclosed within 1 m2 polypropylene enclosures that were cut into the permafrost to a depth of 50 cm. Battery-operated, float-activated pumps were installed to a maximum depth of 50 cm within each polypropylene enclosure to reduce the water table.

Authors: Johnson, LC; Shaver, GR; Cades, DH; Rastetter, E; Nadelhoffer, K; Giblin, A; Laundre, J; Stanley, A
Title: Plant carbon-nutrient interactions control CO2 exchange in Alaskan wet sedge tundra ecosystems
StressorOneNote: Experimental plots were established on Inlet and Outlet sites in 1988. All treatments were imposed for the entire 8 yr, including the year of this study. Treatments included increased nutrient availability (N as NH4NO3, at 10 g·m-2·yr-1; P as superphosphate at 5 g·m-2·yr-1; and N + P, at the same levels), warming with field greenhouses, warming and N + P fertilization, and light attenuation with shade houses (see Chapin et al. 1995 and Shaver et al. 1998 for details). The fertilization was done each year in a single application early in June. Typically, greenhouses were installed from the beginning of June until the last week of August (6 June for the year of this study) and were installed in the same location each year. Treatment plots were 10 * 5 m except for the greenhouse and shade house plots, which were 5 * 3.5 m. Because of time constraints, we carried out intensive CO2 measurements only on warmed, N + P fertilized, and control plots at both Inlet and Outlet locations.
StressorTwoNote: Experimental plots were established on Inlet and Outlet sites in 1988. All treatments were imposed for the entire 8 yr, including the year of this study. The fertilization was done each year in a single application early in June. Title: Mixture toxicity of copper and diazinon to larvae of the mayfly (Ephoron virgo) judging additivity at different effect levels
StressorOneNote: The effects of copper singly, of diazinon singly, and of copper and diazinon jointly were determined simultaneously. Equitoxic mixtures were prepared by applying the toxic unit concept [3] using previously determined, 96-h LC50 values of 11.8 and 77 mg/L for E. virgo exposed to diazinon and copper, respectively [12]. At the start of the experiments, toxicants were added. Copper was added as CuCl2 (Titrisol, Merck, Darmstadt, Germany), and diazinon (derived from Luxan, Elst, The Netherlands; 99.7% purity) was added using a generator column-derived stock solution in DSW [14]. The nominal test concentrations were 0 (control), 20, 50, 100, 150, and 300 mg/ L for copper and 0 (control), 1, 3, 10, 30, and 100 mg/L for diazinon. The nominal test concentrations for the mixture (as diazinon/copper) were 0/0 (control), 3/19 (0.5 TU), 4.5/25 (0.75 TU), 6/39 (1 TU), 9/58 (1.5 TU), 12/77 (2 TU), and 18/ 116 (2.5 TU) mg/L (tested in triplicate).
StressorTwoNote: The effects of copper singly, of diazinon singly, and of copper and diazinon jointly were determined simultaneously. Authors: Lennon, JT; Smith, VH; Dzialowski, AR
Title: Invasibility of plankton food webs along a trophic state gradient
StressorOneNote: We used three levels of nutrient supply in order to capture a gradient of N and P concentrations found in Midwestern U.S. reservoirs. The low nutrient treatment consisted of eight replicate mesocosms with source water having ambient concentrations of N and P (TN=589+/-19 μg/l; TP=24.6+/-1.60 μg/l; TN:TP=24 by mass). We then added sufficient volumes of dissolved KNO3 and KH2PO4 to the remaining 16 mesocosms to achieve eight replicates of the medium nutrient treatment (target TP=50 μg/l) and eight replicates of the high nutrient treatment (target TP=75 μg/l). The target nutrient concentrations were maintained over the course of the experiment by adding dissolved N and P every seven days assuming a loss rate of 5% per day due to sedimentation (V.H. Smith, unpubl.).
StressorTwoNote: We collected Daphnia lumholtzi from Clinton Reservoir located approximately 3 km west of the Univ. of Kansas. This 2 800 ha, multipurpose impoundment has supported populations of invasive D. lumholtzi since at least 1994 (W. J. O'Brien, pers. commun.). From live samples, we isolated a total of 1200 gravid D. lumholtzi under a dissecting microscope. One-hundred D. lumholtzi were then randomly assigned to four replicate tanks in each of the three nutrient treatments; these 12 mesocosms served as the invasion treatment. The relatively low inoculum size (0.33 animals/l) was intended to simulate the propagule pressure of a natural invasion (Neill 1978, Vanni 1986). The remaining 12 mesocosms not inoculated with D. lumholtzi served as the invasion reference.

Authors: Edginton, AN; Sheridan, PM; Stephenson, GR; Thompson, DG; Boermans, HJ
Title: Comparative effects of pH and Vision (R) herbicide on two life stages of four anuran amphibian species
SingleSpecies: rana clamitans; r. pipiens; bufo americanus; xenopus laevis
StressorOneNote: Vision(R), a glyphosate-based herbicide containing a 15% (weight:weight) polyethoxylated tallow amine surfactant blend, and the concurrent factor of pH were tested to determine their interactive effects on early life-stage Rana clamitans, R. pipiens, Bufo americanus, and Xenopus laevis. Ninety-six-hour laboratory static renewal studies, using the embryonic and larval life stages were performed under a central composite rotatable design using Vision concentrationsdetermined based on preliminary dose-response studies at pH 5.5 and pH 7.5 using concentrations ranging from 0.1 to 20 mg a.e./L. pH levels used in the definitive tests were 4.5, 5.0, 6.5, 8.0, and 8.5. Each embryonic experimental unit consisted of a 6015-mm plastic petri dish containing 20 embryos in 10 ml of treatment solution. Larval experimental units consisted of a 2-L aquarium containing 10 healthy Gosner stage 25 larvae in 1 L of treatment solution. The midpoint (0, 0) of the central composite rotatable design was replicated five times. All other design points were replicated once, for a total of 13 experimental units per test (Fig. 1). Each test was replicated twice, totaling 520 embryos and 260 larvae for the embryo and larval data sets, respectively. Two to four replications of the control were used, depending on the availability of animals.
StressorTwoNote: Vision(R), a glyphosate-based herbicide containing a 15% (weight:weight) polyethoxylated tallow amine surfactant blend, and the concurrent factor of pH were tested to determine their interactive effects on early life-stage Rana clamitans, R. pipiens, Bufo americanus, and Xenopus laevis. Ninety-six-hour laboratory static renewal studies, using the embryonic and larval life stages were performed under a central composite rotatable design using Vision concentrationsdetermined based on preliminary dose-response studies at pH 5.5 and pH 7.5 using concentrations ranging from 0.1 to 20 mg a.e./L. pH levels used in the definitive tests were 4.5, 5.0, 6.5, 8.0, and 8.5. Each embryonic experimental unit consisted of a 6015-mm plastic petri dish containing 20 embryos in 10 ml of treatment solution. Larval experimental units consisted of a 2-L aquarium containing 10 healthy Gosner stage 25 larvae in 1 L of treatment solution. The midpoint (0, 0) of the central composite rotatable design was replicated five times. All other design points were replicated once, for a total of 13 experimental units per test (Fig. 1). Each test was replicated twice, totaling 520 embryos and 260 larvae for the embryo and larval data sets, respectively. Two to four replications of the control were used, depending on the availability of animals.

StressorTwoNote: Tiles or leaf packs were attached to frames placed in the stream. To exclude macroconsumers, one frame in each pair was connected to a solar-powered fence charger (Parmak Model DF-SP-SS, Parker McCrory Manufacturing). Each charger contained a 6-V gel cell battery and delivered repeated elec- tric pulses (~54-55 min-1) to the 0.25-m2 frame area at a maximum joule rating of 1.4 J. These electric pulses prevented the entry of fishes and crayfish but did not adversely affect smaller organisms such as aquatic insect larvae. The unelectrified frame in each pair was accessible to macroconsumers and served as a control. The tile experiment lasted 40 days and the leaf pack experiment lasted 56 days.

Authors: Liboriussen, L; Landkildehus, F; Meerhoff, M; Bramm, ME; Sondergaard, M; Christoffersen, K; Richardson, K; Sondergaard, M; Lauridsen, TL; Jeppesen, E
Title: Global warming: Design of a flow-through shallow lake mesocosm climate experiment
StressorOneNote: IPCC climate scenario A2 (Houghton et al. 2001) and A2 + 50% scaled to local conditions in the region (average over five 25 * 25 km grid cells [pers. comm. O. Bossing Christensen, Danish Meteorological Institute]) were applied as the low and high warming scenarios, respectively. The climate scenario A2 models actually predict air temperatures. However, because the temperature of surface waters closely follows that of the air in shallow lakes, we chose to use the modeled air temperatures as a surrogate of water temperatures. Warming was calculated as the mean air temperature increases in one particular month with respect to a 30-y reference period (1961 to 1990) and the modeled temperatures in the same month in 2071 to 2100 (Fig. 3). The modeled temperature difference for the A2 scenario is generally higher in August to January (max: 4.4°C in September) than during the rest of the year (min: 2.5°C in June).
StressorTwoNote: Half of the mesocosms are enriched with nitrogen and phosphorus while the other half remain unenriched. Throughout the first year, nutrients were added weekly as Na2HPO4 and Ca(NO3)2 solutions with a constant loading of 54 mg P and 538 mg N per mesocosm each week (2.7 mg P m-2 d-1 and 27.1 mg N m-2 d-1).

Sediment (200 g) was placed in acid washed 1-L beakers (four replicates per treatment), then 400 mL water with the same salinity as the sediment porewater was added to each beaker
StressorTwoNote: A metal mixture of copper (CuCl2·2H2O), lead (Pb(NO3)2) and zinc (ZnCl2) was used to spike the sediments. Control sediments were spiked with Milli-RO water.

The EF continued for the first two cycles only (June 17 through July 17) while the CF was flooded June 17 through September 23 (Fig- ure 1). IF and EF mesocosms when not flooded were watered like the control as needed to sustain plant growth.
StressorTwoNote: Nutrient loading treatments con- sisted of high, low, and no nutrients additions using Forever Green Lawn Builder Turf Food (Eau Claire Crop Oil Company, Eau Claire, Wis- consin, USA) containing 27% nitrogen (1.2% ammonium N; 25.8% urea N), 3% available phosphate (P2O5), 4% soluble potash (K2O), 1% sulfur, and 1% iron (all percents are by weight). The high nutrient treatment followed the rate rec- ommended by the fertilizer manufacturer (1 lb/ 275 sq ft, applied 3-4 times during the growing season) while the low nutrient treatment was 1/4 the recommended rate. The total amount of nutrients added to mesocosms over the 3 applications (g m^-2 /year) was 14.21 g N, 1.58 g P, and 2.10 g K in the high treatment and 3.55g N, 0.395g P, and 0.526g K in the low treatment.

Authors: Lin, LL; Janz, DM
Title: Effects of binary mixtures of xenoestrogens on gonadal development and reproduction in zebrafish
StressorOneNote: At 2 days post-hatch (dph), fry were exposed to nominal concentrations of EE (1 or 10 ng/l; denoted EE1 or EE10), NP (10 or 100 μg/l; denoted NP10 or NP100), EE + NP (1 ng/l + 10 μg/l, 1 ng/l + 100 μg/l, 10 ng/l + 10 μg/l, or 10 ng/l + 100 μg/l; denoted EE1 + NP10, EE1 + NP100, EE10 + NP10, or EE10 + NP100) or acetone solvent (control) at a 1 μl/ml total dilution in system water. There were three replicate aquaria for each test chemical concentration and solvent control. A 100% water change was performed every 48 h from 2 to 60 dph. Fresh acetone or test chemicals were added at the time of each water change. From 2 to 30 dph, fry were fed an alternating diet of Paramecium multimicronucleatum or freshly hatched brine shrimp three times daily. At 7 dph, fry were transferred to aerated 250 ml beakers. At 30 dph, fry were transferred to aerated 1 l glass beakers, and an alternating diet of flake food and newly hatched brine shrimp was provided twice daily. Chemical exposures continued until 60 dph. At 60 dph, 42 fish (14 fish per replicate) from each treatment group were randomly selected for measurement of lengths, weights, histological examination of the gonads, HSP70 and VTG determinations. Remaining fish were transferred to 20 l glass aquaria and reared in dechlorinated municipal tap water to allow a 6 month depuration period until 240 dph, at which time breeding trials were conducted.
StressorTwoNote: At 2 days post-hatch (dph), fry were exposed to nominal concentrations of EE (1 or 10 ng/l; denoted EE1 or EE10), NP (10 or 100 μg/l; denoted NP10 or NP100), EE + NP (1 ng/l + 10 μg/l, 1 ng/l + 100 μg/l, 10 ng/l + 10 μg/l, or 10 ng/l + 100 μg/l; denoted EE1 + NP10, EE1 + NP100, EE10 + NP10, or EE10 + NP100) or acetone solvent (control) at a 1 μl/ml total dilution in system water. Remaining fish were transferred to 20 l glass aquaria and reared in dechlorinated municipal tap water to allow a 6 month depuration period until 240 dph, at which time breeding trials were conducted.

In preliminary studies with diVer- ent resource manipulations (0.001-0.1 mg l!1 yeast extract), this concentration was found to suYciently induce nutrient-mediated eVects on ciliate abundances and also avoided quick (<5 days) disruption of the experiments due to strong bacterial production.

Authors: Graham, MD; Vinebrooke, RD
Title: Extreme weather events alter planktonic communities in boreal lakes
StressorOneNote: Three temperature treatment levels (control, warm, and cold) were used. All thermally manipulated meso- cosms consisted of a double-layer polypropylene liner separated by an insulation barrier. Warm events were achieved by trapping solar irradiance using 98% UV- transparent acrylic (AcryliteH OP4) greenhouse canopies that were positioned on top of the nine double-walled insulated mesocosms. Canopies were secured above the warmed mesocosms using weather stripping. Supplemental warming events were performed every 3 d during the experiment using sealed 20-L carboys filled with heated water. The method of warming was designed to both passively track and increase natural fluctuations in midsummer epilimnetic temperatures as opposed to main- taining an elevated and constant increase in temperature. Cold events were achieved on 3-d intervals using sealed 20- L carboys containing ice. The canopies were raised 3 cm above the cold and control mesocosms to maximize convective heat loss. Control mesocosms consisted of single-walled, noninsulated polypropylene bag
StressorTwoNote: There were three terrigenic treatment levels (control, [+] terrestrial runoff, [-] terrestrial runoff). The amended treatment level consisted of the addition of highly colored surface water runoff that had been collected from a nearby ephemeral stream following an intense rainfall event in late June 2004. The terrigenic stock solution contained elevated concentrations of dissolved organic carbon (DOC 5 24.5 mg /L) and nutrients (total dissolved nitrogen [TDN]=  554 ug /L; total dissolved phosphorus [TDP] = 11 ug/L; total silica [TSi] = 3.5 mg L21). Amendments simulated a doubling of ambient DOC  from 4.5 to 10 mg L/L. Removal of DOC was achieved by serial filtration of lake water through a 5-micron polypropylene sediment cartridge and a 25-kg layer of activated charcoal.

The UV lamp was placed 30 cm above the vials and a clear cellulose acetate sheet (0.003 mm) was coupled to the lamp to cut-off UV-C range wavelengths. The average intensity of UVA and UVB (290-400 nm) transmitted by the UV lamp was 27,00 mW m-2 (+/-3,0) through all the exposures. The UV dose (J m-2) was obtained by taking into account the time of exposure and was calculated as: UV dose (J m-2) = 10 * UV intensity (mW m-2) * time of exposure (s)/1000
StressorTwoNote: The experimental design included ten replicates per concentration of chemical plus a control. Authors: Bjergager, MBA; Hanson, ML; Solomon, KR; Cedergreen, N
Title: Synergy between prochloraz and esfenvalerate in Daphnia magna from acute and subchronic exposures in the laboratory and microcosms
StressorOneNote: The pesticides were tested as individual compounds and using two types of mixture setups: (1) An equitoxic mixture where 50% of the effect was calculated to come from esfenvalerate and 50% from prochloraz, based on the obtained EC50 of the single compounds and Concentration Addition (CA). This was done to assess the maximal synergy possible between the two compounds. (2) A design where esfenvalerate was tested alone and together with 90 μg L-1 prochloraz. This was done to mimic the exposure in the microcosms (Bjergager et al., 2011). For the first mixture design 0.06, 0.12, 0.24, 0.48, 0.96, 1.92 and 3.84 μg L-1 esfenvalerate and 0.09, 1.08, 2.15, 4.3, 8.6 and 17.2 mg L-1 prochloraz was used for the single compound testing, while the mixture consisted of the esfenvalerate (μg L-1): prochloraz (mg L-1) concentration combinations 0.001:0.017, 0.002:0.033, 0.004:0.067, 0.008:0.134, 0.015:0.268, 0.030:0.538, 0.060:1.075, 0.12:2.15, 0.24:4.30, 0.48:8.60, 0.96:17.2. Authors: Eros, T; Gustafsson, P; Greenberg, LA; Bergman, E
Title: Forest-Stream Linkages: Effects of Terrestrial Invertebrate Input and Light on Diet and Growth of Brown Trout (Salmo trutta) in a Boreal Forest Stream
StressorOneNote: To reduce terrestrial invertebrate input, 2.5 m high plastic tentssupported  by  wooden  frames  were  built  over  the  entire  TRandTRL  enclosures.  The  tent  covers  were  made  of  UV-resistant,95%-transparent greenhouse plastic, attached to both the woodenframes  and  the  ground  floor.  To  ensure  that  drifting  terrestrialinput would be low, an additional 20 m long tent section was builtupstream  each  TRand  TRL  enclosure.  Each  end  of  the  tentenclosure was covered with mosquito-netting, with a small openingnear  the  top  to  reduce  influx  of  aerial  insects,  but  allowingemerging insects from within the tent to leave. In addition, eight40615 cm  openings  were  cut  into  the  roof  of  the  tent  to  allowinsects to leave the covered enclosures. To control for the physicalpresence of the wooden frames, we put up the same type of framesover the U and L enclosures
StressorTwoNote: Toincreaselightlevels,weused8lamphouses(150630610 cm)  equipped  with  two  fluorescent  tubes  (TL-D840,  58 W,  1200630 mm)  per  lamp  in  each  enclosure.  Thefluorescent   tubes   imitate   photosynthetic   active   radiation   withwavelengths mainly between 400 and 700 nm. The lamp houseswere hung, c. 50 cm apart and 60 cm above the stream bottom,from  the  wooden  frames.  Originally  the lamps  were  hung  about40 cm from the stream bottom but due to spring floods at the endof May the lamps had to be raised 20 cm. By doing so the amountof   PAR   (photosynthetic   active   radiation)   reaching   the   watersurface  decreased  from  about  65  to  45-50mmol m22s21.

StressorOneNote: Treatments were achieved by direct application (See below) of the glyphosate-based herbicide Roundup WeatherMax (Monsanto, Winnipeg, MB, CAN) at one of two concentrations, alone and in the presence of nutrient additions to the surface of the wetlands. Nutrient treatments were designed to increase the trophic status of each wetland one level (e.g., oligotrophic to mestrophic) above background levels (calculated in 2008 - one year prior to chemical treatment). Nitrogen and phosphorus were added to wetlands as nitric acid or phosphoric acid at the same ratio as measured one year before treatments were applied. (1) A low aqueous glyphosate concentration (L=210 μg a.e./L), which is the upper 99th percentile concentration of glyphosate observed in wetlands in agricultural areas in Southern Ontario (Byer et al., 2008, Struger et al., 2008). (2) A high target aqueous glyphosate concentration (H=2880 μg a.e./L) which is the concentration expected in a 15 cm deep wetland with no intercepting vegetation that has been oversprayed at the maximum label rate (7.9 L product/ha). (3) The low target aqueous glyphosate concentration with nutrient additions (LN). (4) The high target aqueous glyphosate concentration with nutrient additions (HN).
StressorTwoNote: Treatments were achieved by direct application (See below) of the glyphosate-based herbicide Roundup WeatherMax (Monsanto, Winnipeg, MB, CAN) at one of two concentrations, alone and in the presence of nutrient additions to the surface of the wetlands. Nutrient treatments were designed to increase the trophic status of each wetland one level (e.g., oligotrophic to mestrophic) above background levels (calculated in 2008 - one year prior to chemical treatment). Nitrogen and phosphorus were added to wetlands as nitric acid or phosphoric acid at the same ratio as measured one year before treatments were applied. (1) A low aqueous glyphosate concentration (L=210 μg a.e./L), which is the upper 99th percentile concentration of glyphosate observed in wetlands in agricultural areas in Southern Ontario (Byer et al., 2008, Struger et al., 2008). (2) A high target aqueous glyphosate concentration (H=2880 μg a.e./L) which is the concentration expected in a 15 cm deep wetland with no intercepting vegetation that has been oversprayed at the maximum label rate (7.9 L product/ha). (3) The low target aqueous glyphosate concentration with nutrient additions (LN). (4) The high target aqueous glyphosate concentration with nutrient additions (HN).

Separate temperature sensors in each of the ambient and heated sections continuously controlled a closed flow system of heated media from an air-source heat pump (to the individual heat exchangers). The ΔT of the closed flow system and the flow of water from each pond section was c. 3 °C.

Title: Joint effects of climate warming and exotic litter (Eucalyptus globulus Labill.) on stream detritivore fitness and litter breakdown
StressorOneNote: In Chile, we ran the experiment in two large polystyrene containers (95 * 50 * 25 cm), which were half filled with tap water and kept at different temperatures (8 and 15 °C).; In Spain, we ran the experiment in eight 100 * 11 * 6 cm PVC channels filled with dechlorinated tap water (80 %) and stream water (20 %) which had been mixed 1 week before the beginning of the experiment. Water flowed from the channel into a downstream container, from which it was returned to the upstream end of the channel through plastic tubing using a pump. The two temperature treatments in this case were 13 °C (the stream temperature at the time of collection and the mean stream temperature at the month of collection) and 18 °C (the mean stream temperature at the hottest month).
StressorTwoNote: Both experiments used the following leaf treatments: native leaves only (N); Eucalyptus leaves only (E); both native and Eucalyptus leaves (N + E); and native leaves plus Eucalyptus leaves enclosed in 55-µm mesh bags, so only native leaves were available for detritivores but the water contained Eucalyptus leachates (N + EL). Each replicate had six leaf discs available for detritivores, which were either of the same species (6N or 6E) or both species (3N + 3E); treatment N + EL contained six discs of the native species plus three discs of Eucalyptus enclosed in the mesh bags. Total leaf dry mass initially available for detritivores was 0.26 mg +/- 0.08 SD in Chile and 0.22 mg +/- 0.02 SD in Spain.

Authors: Badiou, PHJ; Goldsborough, LG
Title: Ecological impacts of an exotic benthivorous fish, the common carp (Cyprinus carpio L.), on water quality, sedimentation, and submerged macrophyte biomass in wetland mesocosms
StressorOneNote: We wanted to determine if carp and nutrients interacted synergistically to increase phytoplankton biomass. A two-by-three duplicated, factorial design had the following treatments:(1) control with no fish and no nutrients (CON), (2) low carp density (600-720 kgha-1) and no nutrient enrichment (LOW), (3) high carp density (1320-1720 kgha-1) and no nutrient enrichment (HI), (4) no carp and nutrient enrichment (NP), (5) low carp density and nutrient enrichment (LOW-NP), and (6) high carp density and nutrient enrichment (HI-NP). Nutrients were added every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 13 June to 19 August as a liquid mixture of sodium nitrate (NaNO3) and sodium phosphate dibasic dihydrate (Na2HPO4·2H2O)

Authors: Chappuis, E; Lumbreras, A; Ballesteros, E; Gacia, E
Title: Deleterious interaction of light impairment and organic matter enrichment on Isoetes lacustris (Lycopodiophyta, Isoetales)
StressorOneNote: Levels of light attenuation correspond to the average light levels found at the lower bathymetric distribution of Isoetes lacustris in the lakes present in the area of study (L65) and at 5.5 m depth (L35), where no Isoetes lacustris are found in non-disturbed lakes, although they can survive there if transplanted or after damming (authors pers. obs.). Light attenuation was obtained with neutral shading screens set at 20 cm above the plant canopy and covering an area wider than the plots to avoid light coming from the sides. The percentage of light attenuation was measured below the water surface and below the screen at canopy level at noon on a clear day using a SPQA spherical quantum sensor LiCor coupled to a LiCor Li-1000 data logger.
StressorTwoNote: Organic matter enrichment was achieved by covering the plots with a 1-cm layer of lake sediment Hydrobiologia (2015) 760:145-158 147 123 mixed with fresh horse faeces collected from nearby grasslands. The mixture was prepared in situ, spread evenly on top of the plots forming a layer at the base of the plants that covered only the first centimetre of the leaves of the 9.8-cm canopy height. Samples of the lake surface sediment and of the homogenised mixture with horse faeces were taken to the laboratory and their organic matter content was calculated by weight loss-on-ignition following the protocol described in Chappuis et al. (2014). Results showed that the mixture had reached an organic content enrichment of the 10% of the dry weight (DW), which would correspond to levels found in a pond highly frequented by livestock. Dung input leads to an increase of nutrients in the sediment and also increases the adjacent water orthophosphate, conductivity and turbidity, while dissolved oxygen decreases (Croel & Kneitel, 2011), which are water quality changes related to a shift towards a eutrophic state. Plots with organic matter enrichment were located at least 3 m away from the non-enriched plots to avoid contamination.

StressorOneNote: Our objectives were to investigate the accumulation of dietary triclosan and its neuroendocrine effects in Atlantic croaker, an estuarine fish, under two temperatures and during depuration. A pilot study was used to select a dietary exposure of 50 mg/kg. For 10 days, fish were exposed to one of: 1) low temperature (26c) and triclosan, 2) low temperature and no triclosan (low temperature control), 3) high temperature (29c) and triclosan, and 4) high temperature and no triclosan (high temperature control). (n = 16/treatment): normal diet at 26 °C and 29 °C and triclosan-treated diet at 26 °C and 29 °C.
StressorTwoNote: Our objectives were to investigate the accumulation of dietary triclosan and its neuroendocrine effects in Atlantic croaker under two temperatures and during depuration. A pilot study was used to select a dietary exposure of 50 mg/kg. For 10 days, fish were exposed to one of: 1) low temperature (26c) and triclosan, 2) low temperature and no triclosan (low temperature control), 3) high temperature (29c) and triclosan, and 4) high temperature and no triclosan (high temperature control). (n = 16/treatment): normal diet at 26 °C and 29 °C and triclosan-treated diet at 26 °C and 29 °C.

Authors: Yu, TL; Pang, RH; Chen, K
Title: Plasticity in metamorphic traits of Chinese brown frog (Rana chensinensis) tadpoles: the interactive effects of food level and rearing temperature
StressorOneNote: We used aquarium heaters or cooling units equipped with thermostats to raise the water temperature to 28.1 and 30.2°C, or reduce the temperature to 23.2°C. Two temperatures (23.2 and 25.3°C) were chosen because they fall within the range this species experiences in the field and lab (Wang et al., 2004, 2005), while 28.1°C may approach avoidance temperature (Wang & Li, 2007). We excluded the highest temperature treatments (30.2°C) because survival was less than 20% under the high food level.  Half of the tadpoles in each temperature treatment were placed on a low food level (LFL, 30-40 mg of commercial fish food per tadpole) and half were placed on a high food level (HFL, 60-80 mg per tadpole).
StressorTwoNote: We used aquarium heaters or cooling units equipped with thermostats to raise the water temperature to 28.1 and 30.2°C, or reduce the temperature to 23.2°C. The microcystins present were identified as MC-RR (1462.4 μg.g-1 DW), MC-LR (1087.9 μg.g-1 DW), MC YR (95.9 μg.g-1 DW) and unidentified (51.7 μg.g-1 DW). Total microcystin concentration was 2697.9 μg.g-1 DW; hence 3% of cyanobacterial biomass added to the feed corresponded to 81 mg MCs.kg-1 feed (Table 1). Title: Responses to nitrate pollution, warming and density in common frog tadpoles (Rana temporaria)
StressorOneNote: Water temperature was either ambient (unmanipulated) or artificially increased. Warm temperature was achieved by placing a 100 W aquarium heater on the bottom of the mesocosm, set to operate at 24°C and turned on between 08:00 h and 17:00 h each day. Surface temperature in the warm treatment averaged 3.2°C higher than in the ambient treatment in late afternoon and 2.5°C higher in early morning (see online Supplementary Appendix A).
StressorTwoNote: Nitrogen treatments included an unmanipulated control and a nitrogen-addition treatment. Each mesocosm in the high-nitrogen treatment received a single aliquot of 41.6 ml from a stock solution (76.8 g NH4NO3/l) diluted with 958.4 ml of dechlorinated tap water, mimicking a single pulse of pollution. This was done on 6 April, one day after the tadpoles were introduced. The nominal concentration in the high-nitrogen treatment was 39.9 mg/l NH4NO3, corresponding to 9 mg/l NH4-NH4NO3 and 31 mg/l NO3- NH4NO3.

Authors: Hallman, TA; Brooks, ML
Title: Metal-mediated climate susceptibility in a warming world: Larval and latent effects on a model amphibian
StressorOneNote: These created 3 environmentally relevant temperature regimes: 1) ambient, 2) ambient +1.5 +/- 0.03 °C (average +/- standard error), and 3) ambient + 2.5 +/- 0.05 °C (Figure 2). Temperatures within the water baths were monitored hourly using Hobo U20 data loggers placed at each end. Compared to temperatures in 3 shaded ponds, temperatures in the ambient treatment had virtually identical amplitude and frequency and fell within the same 26 °C to 36 °C range. Also, we measured temperatures daily inside and immediately outside 8 different random mesocosms within each of the 3 large water baths. Temperatures inside and outside of the mesocosms were virtually identical because water levels were the same inside and outside of aquaria. The system maintained low standard errors of +/-0.05 within water baths across the duration of the chronic experiment (33 d).
StressorTwoNote: Ubiquitous environmental pollutants do not exist in isolation, so chronic bioassays followed a 6 * 3 factorial design of 6 sublethal mixtures of Cd, Cu, and Pb (Table 2) versus the 3 temperature regimes discussed above. The lowest of the 6 mixtures was the baseline lake water as a background treatment that contained low metals concentrations, consistent with the ubiquitous, worldwide distribution of sublethal pollutants (as discussed above). Each treatment had 4 replicates for a total of 72 mesocosms (3 temperature regimes * 6 metals concentrations * 4 replicates = 72 mesocosms).

More explicitly, for embryos exposure, stock solution contained 0.03 mg Cu2+/L and 27.15 mg diazinon/L, 1.5 times their respective 168-h LC50, the proportion employed were 1:1 (1 TU Cu/1 TU diazinon). For non-equitoxic mixtures 3 TU Cu/ 2 TU diazinon and 2 TU Cu/1 TU diazinon were tested for embryos, while 2 TU Cu/ 3 TU diazinon and 1 TU Cu/ 2 TU diazinon were assessed for larvae. StressorOneNote: 700 naturally sources developing spotted salamander, Ambystoma maculatum, eggs were placed into 100 * 15 mm petri dishes containing fresh FETAX solution. In total, 700 fertilized eggs were placed from these petri dishes into 70 beakers containing increasing 250-ml prepared test solutions (7 concentrations, 10 replicate beakers per concentration, 10 eggs per beaker). The 10 replicates were divided into three replicate experiments through the breeding season. Developing larvae were placed in an incubator, covered to prevent solution loss due to evaporation, and maintained at 24ºC for 12 d, below the thermal maximum for this species of 28.1-37.9ºC. At the beginning day of each experiment, stock solutions containing 2000 mg/L As(V), 2000 mg/L Cr(VI), and 2500 As(V):1000 mg/L Cr(VI), respectively, were made by dissolving appropriate amounts of each salt in 200 ml FETAX solution (approximately 1666.7 mg Na2HAsO4·7H2O in 200 ml FETAX solution). Stock solutions were then used to prepare 1-L test solutions with concentrations of 0.02, 0.2, 2, 20, and 200 mg/L As(V) and Cr(VI), respectively, and 0.025:0.01, 0.25:0.1, 2.5:1, 25:10, and 250:100 mg/L As(V):Cr(VI) using serial dilution. Developing larvae were kept in solutions made at the beginning of each assay for 12 d, 2 d post hatch, exposed to As(V) and Cr(VI) from Harrison stages 11 through 44.

Authors: Diaz Pauli, B; Kolding, J; Jeyakanth, G; Heino, M
Title: Effects of ambient oxygen and size-selective mortality on growth and maturation in guppies
StressorOneNote: Size selection linked to harvesting. The test fish were first-generation (F1) offspring from six replicate laboratory populations that had experienced size-selective mortality for 3.1 years (approximately four generations). These populations represent two treatments, with three replicates each, as follows: (i) positive size-selected line, in which large individuals [>16mm standard length (SL)] were removed from the population every sixth week; and (ii) negative- size selected line, in which individuals smaller than 16mm were removed at equal intervals.
StressorTwoNote: Two oxygen treatments: (i) high oxygen, with 95 +/- 5%oxygen saturation, corresponding to ~7.9 +/- 0.4 mg l-1; or (ii) low oxygen, with 64%+/- 6% oxygen saturation (5.3 +/- 0.5mg l-1).

Authors: Olsen, S; Cao, Y; Gutierrez, MF; Brucet, S; Landkildehus, F; Lauridsen, TL; Davidson, TA; Sondergaard, M; Jeppesen, E; Risgaard-Petersen, N
Title: Effect of a nitrogen pulse on ecosystem N processing at different temperatures: A mesocosm experiment with (NO3-)-N-15 addition
StressorOneNote: The mesocosms consist of cylindrical stainless steel tanks (1.9 m diameter, 1.5 m height [2.8 m3]) that were established and have been maintained since August 2003 at three contrasting temperatures: ambient, T3 (heating according to the IPCC 2007 A2 scenario, +3.7-4.5°C, depending on season) and T5 (heating with A2 + 50%, +4.9-6.6°C) (Solomon, 2007), with four replicates of each (Liboriussen et al., 2005).
StressorTwoNote: To measure N uptake and transportation after an N pulse at three contrasting temperatures, we added 5.8 g 15N as K15NO3- (98 atom % 15N) to each mesocosm once to increase the NO3- in the mesocosms from c. 0.2 to 2 mg/L. The K15NO3- was applied after diluting it into a small amount of water from each mesocosm and pouring it evenly across the water surface. Water chemistry, chlorophyll a (Chl a) and isotope samples were taken 4 days prior to the 15N addition (day -4), subsequent to the 15N addition (day 1) and 3, 8, 10, 15, 22, 31, 59, 79, 105 and 135 days after the addition.

Authors: Pereira, AS; Cerejeira, MJ; Daam, MA
Title: Toxicity of environmentally realistic concentrations of chlorpyrifos and terbuthylazine in indoor microcosms
StressorOneNote: Terbuthylazine (TBZ; Chemical Abstracts Service [CAS] number 5915-41-3; purity 98.6%) and chlorpyrifos (CPF; CAS number 2921- 88-2; purity 98%) were purchased from SigmaeAldrich. Treatment levels of terbuthylazine (8.5 mg/L) and chlorpyrifos (0.17 mg/L), individually and as a binary mixture, were selected from concentrations measured simultaneously in the Leziria Grande de Vila Franca de Xira agricultural area, situated in the vicinity of the River Tagus Estuary Natural Reserve (Portugal). Terbutrylazine (mean +/- SD  1/4 0.33 +/- 1.2 mg/L; max.  1/4 8.5 mg/L) and chlorpyrifos (mean +/- SD  1/4 0.56 +/- 2.6 mg/L; max.  1/4 12 mg/L) co-occurred in approximately half (48%) of the 54 samples taken in May to July 2014. In line with the maximum concentration of 8.5 mg/L terbuthylazine measured at this field site, similar (maximum) concentrations have been reported in several other studies (5.6e9.6 mg/L; Baillie, 2016; Knauer, 2016; Tsaboula et al., 2016).
StressorTwoNote: Terbuthylazine (TBZ; Chemical Abstracts Service [CAS] number 5915-41-3; purity 98.6%) and chlorpyrifos (CPF; CAS number 2921- 88-2; purity 98%) were purchased from SigmaeAldrich. In line with the maximum concentration of 8.5 mg/L terbuthylazine measured at this field site, similar (maximum) concentrations have been reported in several other studies (5.6e9.6 mg/L; Baillie, 2016; Knauer, 2016; Tsaboula et al., 2016).

StressorOneNote: Silver was added to the stream water as citrate coated AgNPs (8 levels: 50 to 75000 μg L- 1) or AgNO3 (8 levels: 5 to 7500 μg L- 1). One set of microcosms was incubated at 16 °C, a temperature commonly found in streams of NW Portugal in autumn, another set at 10 °C and 23 °C to simulate possible scenarios in a climate change (seasonal temperature extremes). All microcosms (total of 153 microcosms) were kept on a shaker (120 rpm) for 21 days and solutions were renewed every 7 days.

After the heat exposure, all eggs returned to 20 °C. A heat wave was also applied in the laval state (at 35 days). Larvae were exposed to one of three heat wave treatments, being 20 °C, 25 °C and 30 °C for four days.

The exposure conditions were the same as used earlier for the unionid mussels from a pristine site (Falfushynska et al., 2015a). The highest predicted exposure concentration of n-ZnO for aquatic organisms in the EU was ~500 ng/L (~8 nM) (NanoFATE, 2010e2014). In a pilot study,we determined the 96 h LC50 of n-ZnO for a unionid mussel Unio tumidus as 49 mM Zn, and EC50 calculated from the data of neutral red retention test (indicative of lysosomal stability) and micronuclei test (indicative of the genotoxicity), was 15 mM Zn (Stoliar, Falfushynska, unpublished data). Control and experimental exposures were conducted for 14 days. A static renewal design was used, with water changed and chemicals replenished every two days. Mollusks were fed with a commercial food (Aquarius, Ukraine) prior to the water change. Background  concentrations  ofnutrient and emerging contaminants were measured weekly fromwater collected from the channel outlet to assess the possible dif-ferences between nominal and observed concentrations (seeAristiet al., 2016for details).Emerging contaminants were analyzed using a method basedon an online pre-concentration with EQuan MAXTM technologycoupled to a TSQ Vantage triple quadrupole mass spectrometer(Thermo Fisher Scientific, San Jose, U.S.A.) (on-line SPE-LC/MS/MS)equipped with an electrospray ionization source (ESI) (seeAristiet al., 2016for details). Note that the limits of detection (LODs)and quantification (LOQs) were estimated experimentally from realsamples as the concentration of analyte that provides a signal-to-noise ratio of 3 and 10, respectively.2.4. Sampling and sample processingBiofilm samples from each artificial stream were collectedbefore treatment started (at day1), as well as after 14 and 28 days.The top sand layer (1 cm) was collected with a core sampler(diameter 1/41.2 cm), placed in sterile 15-mL polypropylene tubes(Fisher Scientific; Wilmington, DE, USA) and stored at80C untilDNA extraction. Biofilms were detached from sand particles byvortexing for 5 min3 times after adding 5 ml of 10 mM Tris-HCLbuffer at pH 7.5 to each sterile 15-mL polypropylene tubes. Bio-film biomass was then pelleted by centrifugation at 6000 rpm for15 min and genomic DNA was extracted using the PowerSoil DNAisolation Kit (MoBio Laboratories, USA) according to manufacturer'sinstructions. The DNA concentration was measured using Qubit 2.0fluorometer (Life Technologies; Carlsbad, CA, USA) and purity wasdetermined by measuring A260/A230and A260/A280absorbance ra-tios using a NanoDrop 2000 spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific;Wilmington, DE, USA).2.5. Quantification of antibiotic resistance genesCopy numbers of six genes encoding resistance to the antibioticsadded in the mixture of emerging contaminants, namely:sul1andsul2genes conferring resistance to sulfamethoxazole;qnrA,qnrBandqnrS genes conferring resistance to ciprofloxacin and the ermBgene conferring resistance to erythromycin were determined intriplicate using real-time PCR (qPCR) assays. Moreover, copynumbers of the class 1 integron-integrase gene (intI1) and thebacterial 16S rRNA gene were also determined. The abundance ofthe latter was used as a proxy for bacterial abundance and tonormalize the concentration of target ARGs to minimize variationsdue to different DNA extraction efficiency across samples and toprovide an indication of the proportion of total bacterial carryingARGs (Heuer et al., 2011;Pruden et al., 2006).All genes were quantified using primers and conditionscompiled in Supporting InformationTable S1. The standard curveswere carried out as previously described (Subirats et al., 2017). Allreactions were performed using SYBR green detection chemistry ona MX3005 system (Agilent Technologies; Santa Clara, CA, USA), aspreviously described (Marti et al., 2013). Samples were analyzed induplicate with a standard curve and a negative control included ineach run. The specificity of the reaction was verified by meltingcurve analysis and by electrophoresis run. All qPCR assays wereperformed with highR2values (0.998 in average), high efficiencies(91.86+/-3.18%) and a dynamic range of at least 5 orders of magni-tude, thus validating the gene quantification. The limit of quanti-fication of each gene was 18, 100, 80, 56, 250 copiesmL1forqnrS,sul1,sul2,ermB andintI1genes, respectively.2.6. High-throughput sequencing and sequence processingFor community analysis, equimolar amounts of DNA extractedfrom each artificial stream under same treatment conditions werecombined to obtain a composite sample for that treatment. Thesecomposite samples were then subjected to high-throughput mul-tiplexed 16S rRNA gene sequencing with the Illumina MiSeq System(2250 PE) using primer pair 515f/806r (Caporaso et al., 2011)complemented with Illumina adapters and sample-specific barc-odes at the Research Technology Support Facility Michigan StateUniversity, USA (Kozich et al., 2013). Pair merging, qualityfiltering,chimera checking, clustering into Operational Taxonomic Units(OTU, 97% cutoff) and construction of OTU table were carried outusing default parameters in UPARSE (Edgar 2013). The resultingOTU table was converted to Biological Observation Matrix (BIOM)format (Mcdonald et al., 2012) and then imported and analyzed inQIIME (Caporaso et al., 2010). Sequencing depth ranged between167 and 97,540 sequences per sample. The sample with the lowestsequence number (14NE-H, 167 sequences) was removed fromdownstream analysis. OTUs affiliated to eukaryotes (6; 0.2%), algalchloroplasts (83; 3.3%), archaea (8; 0.3%) and unclassifieds (175;6.5%) werefiltered from the original OTU table using appropriatescripts in QIIME. Afterfiltering, we obtained a total number of 2435bacterial OTUs. For community analysis (alpha and beta diversity),the number of sequences in each sample was normalized byrandomly selecting a subset of 27,700 sequences per sample tominimize bias due to different sequencing depth across samples.The sequence data set was deposited in the NCBI Sequence ReadArchive (SRA) database under accession number SRP128512.J. Subirats et al. / Water Research 138 (2018) 77e8579
StressorTwoNote: We used a mixture of 5 emerging contaminants at constantconcentrations of 0.1mgL1of methylparaben and 1mgL1of cip-rofloxacin, diclofenac, erythromycin and sulfamethoxazole. The total concentration ofmethanol reaching the artificial streams was 400 ng L1. The sameconcentration of methanol was added to treatments withoutemerging contaminants.

Authors: Del Rio, AM; Davis, BE; Fangue, NA; Todgham, AE
Title: Combined effects of warming and hypoxia on early life stage Chinook salmon physiology and development
StressorOneNote: Developing Chinook salmon were reared from fertilization to the fry stage in two temperature treatments [10°C (ambient) and 14°C (warm)]. Ambient temperature of 10°C was chosen as this is within the average range of temperatures in the Sacramento River when late fall-run salmon embryos are present (Bureau of Reclamation (2018), Central Valley Operations, Sacramento River Temperature Report). The warm temperature of 14°C was chosen to represent a 4°C increase of water temperatures projected with climate change and is a potentially stressful, but not lethal, temperature because embryo mortality increases around 16°C in California Chinook salmon. Two different temperature treatments were maintained by placing culture and reservoir buckets in four large water bath tanks (1.2 m in diameter) containing flow through water at the corresponding treatment temperature. Each water bath (at 10°C or 14°C) held two culture buckets from the normoxia and hypoxia treatments, with two replicate water bath tanks for each temperature (n = 4 culture buckets per temperature and DO treatment combination).
StressorTwoNote: Two oxygen (O2) saturation levels [normoxia (100% air saturation, 10 mg O2/l) and hypoxia (50% saturation, 5.5 mg O2/l)]. Dissolved oxygen within natural redds can fluctuate widely between 2-11 mg O2/l (Coble, 1961; Peterson and Quinn, 1996). Normoxia was maintained at 100% saturation to represent optimal habitat conditions and 50% was chosen as a moderate level of hypoxia that is potentially stressful, but not lethal. Oxygen saturation was manipulated using mass flow controller valves (Sierra Instruments, Monterey, CA, USA) to mix N2 gas and air to maintain low DO in hypoxic treatments or air alone for normoxic treatments. The gas mixture was bubbled into reservoir buckets using venturi injectors (one reservoir bucket for each temperature * DO treatment).

Authors: Musetta-Lambert, JL; Kreutzweiser, DP; Sibley, PK
Title: Assessing the influence of wildfire on leaf decomposition and macroinvertebrate communities in boreal streams using mixed-species leaf packs
StressorOneNote: The present work, we ask how compositional differences in riparian leaf litter derived from burned and undisturbed forests influence leaf breakdown and macroinvertebrate communities associated with leaf litter subsidies. In addition, we ask whether aquatic macroinvertebrate communities are influenced by changes in the types of leaf litter entering streams after riparian forests have been burned by wildfire. We created five mixed-species leaf pack combinations simulating riparian-derived leaf litter subsidies to streams bordered by undisturbed riparian forest (hereafter, reference-simulated leaf packs, two mixtures) and previously burned riparian forests (hereafter, fire-simulated leaf packs, three mixtures).
StressorTwoNote: The present work, we ask how compositional differences in riparian leaf litter derived from burned and undisturbed forests influence leaf breakdown and macroinvertebrate communities associated with leaf litter subsidies. In addition, we ask whether aquatic macroinvertebrate communities are influenced by changes in the types of leaf litter entering streams after riparian forests have been burned by wildfire. We created five mixed-species leaf pack combinations simulating riparian-derived leaf litter subsidies to streams bordered by undisturbed riparian forest (hereafter, reference-simulated leaf packs, two mixtures) and previously burned riparian forests (hereafter, fire-simulated leaf packs, three mixtures).

Authors: Bernal, L; Dussan, J
Title: Synergistic effect of Lysinibacillus sphaericus and glyphosate on temephos-resistant larvae of Aedes aegypti
StressorOneNote: Monsanto's glyphosate formulation Roundup 747(R) was used as the only source of glyphosate. After the measurements of larval mortality, we observed that the LD50gly was 2.34 g/l (R2 = 0.947; y = 3.452x + 1.6483). This result allows us to use field concentrations of glyphosate (1.69 g/l).
StressorTwoNote: Many microorganisms areused as biological agents against plagues; for example, the mycoparasite fungusTrichoderma harzianum is used against phytopathogenic nspecies, andthe entomopathogenic bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis is applied to crops [17, 18]. Recently, Colombian strains of Lysinibacillus sphaericus, a well-known entomopathogenic gram-positiveinnocuous bacterium, have been shown todemonstrate strong activity against Culex, Aedes and Anopheles larvae[19, 20]. Lysinibacillus sphaericus is not only a very effective biocontrol agentfor mosquito larvae, but it is also capable of removing toxic metals from water, promoting plant growth, and metabolizing glyphosate by a pathway that does not produce AMPA. The strains of L. sphaericus used in this study were the WHO reference strain 2362 and L. sphaericus III(3)7, a Colombian strain isolated from a native oak tree (Quercus humboldtii) [26]. This mixture was previously shown to be the most lethal for Ae. aegypti larvae [27].

Authors: Alkimin, GD; Soares, AMVM; Barata, C; Nunes, B
Title: Can salicylic acid modulate biochemical, physiological and population alterations in a macrophyte species under chemical stress by diclofenac?
StressorOneNote: aim of this work was to investigate the capacity of SA of modulating Lemna minor responses co-exposed to the pharmaceutical drug, diclofenac. To attain this objective, L. minor was exposed for 7 days, to DCF alone, and to combinations of DCF with SA. For the performance of both tests, the nominal adopted DCF concentrations were based on the EC50 of this compound, previously calculated for the test species (7.5 mg/L; Cleuvers, 2003), to assure that plants were exposed to a stressful condition. DCF concentrations to be used in all subsequent experimental testing were then calculated, by dividing this value by 20, 10, and 5 (0.375, 0.75 and 1.5 mg/L, respectively - 1.179, 2.3575 and 4.7151 mM/L, respectively). The adopted, nominal SA concentration (4 μg/L-24.8278 μM/L), was based on already reported environmental concentrations that range between 0.855 and 4.1 μg/L.
StressorTwoNote: aim of this work was to investigate the capacity of SA of modulating Lemna minor responses co-exposed to the pharmaceutical drug, diclofenac. To attain this objective, L. minor was exposed for 7 days, to DCF alone, and to combinations of DCF with SA. For the performance of both tests, the nominal adopted DCF concentrations were based on the EC50 of this compound, previously calculated for the test species (7.5 mg/L; Cleuvers, 2003), to assure that plants were exposed to a stressful condition. Authors: Siddig, AAH; Richardson, JS; Dormann, CF
Title: Drought may amplify the impacts of salt pollution in pond ecosystems: an experimental exploration
StressorOneNote: Presence or absence of drying and water salinization treatments were applied to mimic drought and pollution by salts, respectively, with each of the four combinations replicated five times. First, to mimic presence of pond salinization due to road salts, 28 g of regular table salt (NaCl) was added to increase water salinity to about 0.3 ppt, which exceeds salinity levels for natural ponds (~ 0.1 ppt). We note here that salinity level of 0.3 ppt has been shown to not be lethal to many aquatic organisms, but enough to cause some stress (see Thompson & Shurin 2012). Second, to simulate presence of drought conditions, half of the mesocosms were excluded from topping up of water and left to dry out over the course of the experiment.
StressorTwoNote: Presence or absence of drying and water salinization treatments were applied to mimic drought and pollution by salts, respectively, with each of the four combinations replicated five times. First, to mimic presence of pond salinization due to road salts, 28 g of regular table salt (NaCl) was added to increase water salinity to about 0.3 ppt, which exceeds salinity levels for natural ponds (~ 0.1 ppt). We note here that salinity level of 0.3 ppt has been shown to not be lethal to many aquatic organisms, but enough to cause some stress (see Thompson & Shurin 2012). Second, to simulate presence of drought conditions, half of the mesocosms were excluded from topping up of water and left to dry out over the course of the experiment.

The RCP8.5 represents a future warming scenario with little curbing of emissions and carbon dioxide concentrations reaching 940 ppm by 2100 (CSIRO and Bureau of Meteorology, 2015). Nitrate concentrations were chosen to reflect control (0 mg l-1 NO3-), moderate (50 mg l-1 NO3- - the current recommended maximum level) and high levels (100 mg l-1 NO3-) of nitrate pollution

Each treatment had 10 replicates and 1 neonate (<24 h old) per replicate (n = 10). StressorTwoNote: In the dissolved uptake experiment, cadmium concentration was 0.15 μg/L (22.2 kBq/), with 8 hr exposure. StressorThreeNote: In the dissolved uptake experiment, zinc concentration was 2 μg/L  (2.0 μg/L stable Zn and 55.5 kBq/L Zn [0.03 μg/L]), with 8 hr exposure. In the efflux experiment, neonates were first acclimated in M7 medium containing different Zn concentrations for 3 d using the methods mentioned above, and then radiolabeled in SM7 medium spiked with radioisotopes (55.5 kBq/L of Zn) for 4 days.

Authors: Ferreira, ALG; Loureiro, S; Soares, AMVM
Title: Toxicity prediction of binary combinations of cadmium, carbendazim and low dissolved oxygen on Daphnia magna
StressorOneNote: 2.3.1. Immobilisation tests: chemical mixtures An experimental design which includes simultaneously a single evaluation of each compound and a set of 20 combinations was chosen for binary mixture testing. A ray design (Cassee et al., 1998) was used to assess the mixtures of Cd and CBZ (Fig. 1b). Nominal concentrations of the mixtures were calculated based on expected toxic strengths of 0.25 (0.125 + 0.125), 0.375 (0.125 + 0.25; 0.25 + 0.125), 0.5 (0.125 + 0.375; 0.25 + 0.25; 0.375 + 0.125), 0.75 (0.125 + 0.625; 0.25 + 0.5; 0.375 + 0.375; 0.5 + 0.25; 0.625 + 0.125), 1 (0.125 + 0.875; 0.25 + 0.75; 0.375 + 0.625; 0.5 + 0.5; 0.625 + 0.375; 0.75 + 0.25; 0.875 + 0.125), 1.5 (0.75 + 0.75) and 2 (1 + 1) toxic units (TU). Nominal concentrations of Cd used in single evaluations ranged from 25 to 200g/L and in combined experiments from 15 to 123g/L. For CBZ concentrations ranged from25 to 200g/L and 20 to 157g/L in single and combined experiments, respectively. 48-h LC50 values used for this calculation were obtained frompreviously made experiments with single stressors exposure. Four and two replicates with five organisms each were used for single and combined toxicant experiments, respectively. 2.3.2. Immobilisation tests: combination of chemicals and natural stressor Five concentrations ranging from 25 to 250g/L and 25 to 200g/L ofCdand CBZ, respectively,were testedat six different dissolved oxygen concentrations. To obtain a concentration-response curve for the statistical analysis,where the toxicity increases as concentrations increase, a transformation of [9.0-x]was made, where 9.0 corresponds to the control concentration (9.0mg DO/L) and x is the real concentrations tested (0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0 and 2.5mg DO/L). Three and two replicates with five daphnids each were used for single and combined stressor experiments, respectively. An experimental factorial design was used (Fig. 1a). 2.3.3. Feeding inhibition and post-exposure tests Similarly to acute experiments, the EC50 values obtained from single exposures were also applied to calculate toxic units in compound mixtures. Concentrations ranging from 10 to 50g/L and 25 to 125g/L were used for binary mixtures/combinations of Cd and CBZ, respectively. Again, real DO concentrations of 2.0, 3.0, 4.0, 5.0 and 6.0 mg/L were transformed by [9.0-x], where 9.0mg DO/L corresponds to the control value. One replicate with five daphnids plus a blank were used for each treatment. Both experimental designs showed in Fig. 1 were used in the feeding inhibition tests: a ray design for the chemical mixture, and a factorial design for the combination of DO and the chemical compounds.

StressorThreeNote: 2.3.1. Immobilisation tests: chemical mixtures An experimental design which includes simultaneously a single evaluation of each compound and a set of 20 combinations was chosen for binary mixture testing. A ray design (Cassee et al., 1998) was used to assess the mixtures of Cd and CBZ (Fig. 1b). Nominal concentrations of the mixtures were calculated based on expected toxic strengths of 0.25 (0.125 + 0.125), 0.375 (0.125 + 0.25; 0.25 + 0.125), 0.5 (0.125 + 0.375; 0.25 + 0.25; 0.375 + 0.125), 0.75 (0.125 + 0.625; 0.25 + 0.5; 0.375 + 0.375; 0.5 + 0.25; 0.625 + 0.125), 1 (0.125 + 0.875; 0.25 + 0.75; 0.375 + 0.625; 0.5 + 0.5; 0.625 + 0.375; 0.75 + 0.25; 0.875 + 0.125), 1.5 (0.75 + 0.75) and 2 (1 + 1) toxic units (TU). Nominal concentrations of Cd used in single evaluations ranged from 25 to 200g/L and in combined experiments from 15 to 123g/L. For CBZ concentrations ranged from25 to 200g/L and 20 to 157g/L in single and combined experiments, respectively. 48-h LC50 values used for this calculation were obtained frompreviously made experiments with single stressors exposure. Four and two replicates with five organisms each were used for single and combined toxicant experiments, respectively. 2.3.2. Immobilisation tests: combination of chemicals and natural stressor Five concentrations ranging from 25 to 250g/L and 25 to 200g/L ofCdand CBZ, respectively,were testedat six different dissolved oxygen concentrations. To obtain a concentration-response curve for the statistical analysis,where the toxicity increases as concentrations increase, a transformation of [9.0-x]was made, where 9.0 corresponds to the control concentration (9.0mg DO/L) and x is the real concentrations tested (0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0 and 2.5mg DO/L). Three and two replicates with five daphnids each were used for single and combined stressor experiments, respectively. An experimental factorial design was used (Fig. 1a). 2.3.3. Feeding inhibition and post-exposure tests Similarly to acute experiments, the EC50 values obtained from single exposures were also applied to calculate toxic units in compound mixtures. Concentrations ranging from 10 to 50g/L and 25 to 125g/L were used for binary mixtures/combinations of Cd and CBZ, respectively. Again, real DO concentrations of 2.0, 3.0, 4.0, 5.0 and 6.0 mg/L were transformed by [9.0-x], where 9.0mg DO/L corresponds to the control value. One replicate with five daphnids plus a blank were used for each treatment. Both experimental designs showed in Fig. 1 were used in the feeding inhibition tests: a ray design for the chemical mixture, and a factorial design for the combination of DO and the chemical compounds.

Authors: Ling, XP; Zhang, YH; Lu, YH; Huang, HQ
Title: Superoxide dismutase, catalase and acetylcholinesterase: biomarkers for the joint effects of cadmium, zinc and methyl parathion contamination in water
StressorOneNote: Heavy metals are known to reduce the activities of antioxidant enzymes (e.g. superoxide dismutase, catalase), while organophosphorous insecticides are known to inhibit the activity of the enzyme acetylcholinesterase. In this study, the activities of these three enzymes in zebrafish (Danio rerio) tissues were assessed to evaluate the consequences heavy metal and organophosphate contamination in aquatic systems. Ten randomly selected zebrafish were transferred into a 2 L beaker containing 1 L of dechlorinated tap water. The 96 h LC50 value and 95% confidence interval (CI) of zebrafish treated with water dosed with a single pollutant (MP, Cd or Zn) were measured according to the Spearman-Karber method [18] and the relevant statistics [19]. The single 96 h LC50 value (shown in Table 1) was considered to be one toxic unit, and the joint toxicities of the mixtures (MP + Cd and MP + Zn) were tested using the equal toxic unit method [20].

Title: Nonlinear mixed-modelling discriminates the effect of chemicals and their mixtures on zebrafish behavior
StressorOneNote: Larvae were transferred to each well of a 96-well plate at 80 hpf along with 225 µL of embryo medium and maintained overnight at 28.5 °C. Preliminary work identified that exposure to isoproterenol and serotonin suppressed and stimulated larval locomotor activity, respectively. The next day each well received either 20 µM isoproterenol, 100 µM serotonin or a combination of both and each plate contained 24 wells/larvae per treatment (a total of 3 plates). Final well volume was 300 uL following additions of chemical stocks. Immediately following the chemical exposure, plates were transferred to the Zebrabox and behavioral trials commenced as described previously18, following the lighting regime of Emran et al.8.

The concentrations of Cu used in this study were 10, 25, 50, 75, 100, 150, and 200 mg L1. Three replicates were conducted for each treatment, and fifty daphnids were added to each of the three replicates of each treatment. D. magna exposure was performed in 500 mL beakers containing 500mL test medium and D. magna were not fed during the exposure period. The mortality of the daphnids was assessed by calculating the percentage of daphnids remaining alive at the end of exposure. A control test without Cu contaminant was also conducted under the same conditions.
StressorTwoNote: GN and GO were provided by Nanjing XFNANO Materials Tech Co., Ltd. (China) with purity of 98% and 99%, respectively. The stock suspensions of GN and GO (100 mg L1) were prepared based on the procedure described by Fan et al. (2016) in which 10 mg of GN or GO was transferred to 100 mL ultrapure water and then placed in a bath sonicator at an intensity of 100 W for 2 h in an attempt to obtain the optimal particle dispersion. The stock suspension was stored at room temperature and ultrasonicated for 20 min before use.

Authors: Broughton, RJ; Marsden, ID; Hill, JV; Glover, CN
Title: Interactive effects of hypoxia and dissolved nutrients on the physiology and biochemistry of the freshwater crayfish Paranephrops zealandicus
StressorOneNote: Crayfish were exposed to hypoxia in the presence or absence of nutrients in 450-mL custom-built Perspex respirometry chambers. Chambers were placed in a temperature-controlled water bath set at 158C and, to allow for acclimation, animals were positioned in these chambers at least 12 h before experimentation. During this period, the chambers were supplied with flowing, aerated aquarium water. At the start of exposures, the water in the chambers was rapidly flushed and replaced with fresh aquarium water from one of four reservoirs, representing the four different exposure groups: normoxic water (21 kPa); severe hypoxia (1.3 kPa); severe hypoxia and nitrite (1.3 kPa th 20 mg L 1 nitrite); severe hypoxia and ammonia (1.3 kPa th 30 mg L 1 as total ammonia, 0.04 mg L 1 as un-ionised ammonia). The mean (s.e.m.) mass of all crayfish was 43.0  0.3 g, with no significant differences in mass between experimental treatment groups. There were six to eight replicates in each group. Nutrient additions were made from freshly made stock solutions of 1 M sodium nitrite or ammonium chloride, which did not affect water pH. Respirometry chambers were then sealed, and an initial water sample was taken for determination of pO2. A pO2 sample was then taken after 20 min, immediately before the chambers were flushed with fresh water from the appropriate reservoir, and the protocol was repeated. This protocol continued for 6 h (i.e. 18 consecutive 20-min respirometry periods).

Authors: Aca, VL; Gonzalez, PV; Carriquiriborde, P
Title: Lethal and sublethal responses in the fish, Odontesthes bonariensis, exposed to chlorpyrifos alone or under mixtures with endosulfan and lambda-cyhalothrin
StressorOneNote: Three-L-glass aquaria filled with 2 L testing solutions were used as test chambers. Charcoal-filtered La Plata tap water was used for preparing test media. DMSO was used as solvent vehicle at 0.01% in all concentrations, including the control group. Fish were fed 0.5 ml of 24-h Artemia sp. nauplii concentrate at the 48 h, 1 h before whole testing media volume was renewed. As O. bonariensis is extremely sensitive to handling, media renewal was performed by siphoning the test solutions up to 1 cm above the test chamber bottom and immediately refilled with 2 L fresh media. The siphoning devise was cleaned between treatments and always the procedure was performed from controls to higher concentrations to avoid contamination. Temperature and illumination conditions were the same as the described in the holding conditions. To evaluate lethal effects of CPF, EN, and LC under single exposure, a minimum of five concentrations levels were assessed including the solvent control group. In four of the six repeated experiments with CPF, sublethal effects (AchE activity inhibition) were also assessed in the surviving fish after 96 h of exposure. To evaluate lethal effects of CPF in binary mixtures with LC and EN, five treatments were assessed according with the following toxic units (TU) proportions of CPF and LC or EN, respectively: 1-0, 1/4-3/ 4, 1/2-1/2, 3/4-1/4, and 0-1. Therefore, one TU would be expected in all treatments assuming additive effect. The sublethal effects of the binary mixtures on AchE activity were assessed in surviving fish of two of the six repeated experiments.

Authors: Salerno, J; Gillis, PL; Khan, H; Burton, E; Deeth, LE; Bennett, CJ; Sibley, PK; Prosser, RS
Title: Sensitivity of larval and juvenile freshwater mussels (unionidae) to ammonia, chloride, copper, potassium, and selected binary chemical mixtures
StressorOneNote: With growing interest in understanding the risk that chemical mixtures pose to mussels, this investigation focused on the effects of various waterborne contaminants (ammonia, chloride, copper, and potassium) and selected binary mixtures of these chemicals following a fixed-ratio design to Villosa iris glochidia and juvenile Lampsilis fasciola. All factor levels in 48 are: ammonia chloride (7.4 [95% confidence interval (CI) 6.6-8.2] mg N/L), ammonia sulfate (8.4 [7.6-9.1] mg N/L), copper sulfate (14.2 [12.9-15.4] μg Cu2+/L), potassium chloride (12.8 [11.9-13.7] mg K+/L), potassium sulfate (10.1 [8.9-11.2] mg K+/L), and sodium chloride (480.5 [435.5-525.5] mg Cl-/L). The 7-d LC50 values for juvenile L. fasciola were determined for potassium sulfate (45.0 [18.8-71.2] mg K+/L), and sodium chloride (1738.2 [1418.6-2057.8] mg Cl-/L). Data from binary mixture exposures for V. iris glochidia (chloride-ammonia, chloride-copper, and copper-ammonia) and juvenile L. fasciola (chloride-potassium) were analyzed using a regression-based, dose-response mixture analysis modeling framework.

Authors: Soares, MP; Machado, AL; Hayd, L; Soares, A; Domingues, I
Title: Effects of pH and nitrites on the toxicity of a cypermethrin-based pesticide to zebrafish embryos
StressorOneNote: ebrafish culture water with different pH (6, 7.5 and 9) was prepared using specific buffers (from Sigma-Aldrich(R)) for pH stabilization. For pH 6.0 the 2- (N-Morpholino) ethanesulfonic acid hydrate, 4- Morpholineethanesulfonic acid (MES) buffer was used (780 mg/L); for pH 7.5 the 3- (N-Morpholino) propanesulfonic acid, 4- Morpholinepropanesulfonic acid (MOPS) buffer was used (837 mg/L); and for pH 9.0 the 2- (Cyclohexylamino) ethanesulfonic acid (CHES) buffer was used (1560 mg/L). Buffers were diluted in fish culture water and pH adjusted with hydrochloric acid - HCl or sodium hydroxide - NaOH with the help of a portable multi-parameter device (Consort C5020). Barrage(R) was then added to the pH-corrected water. Barrage(R) (Zoetis-Fort Dodge, Campinas, SP, Brazil) is a concentrated, emulsifiable suspension containing 150 g/L of cypermethrin (α-cyano-3-phenoxybenzyl- 2,2-dimethyl-3- (2,2-dichlorovinyl) -cyclopropanecarboxylate, C22H19Cl2NO3, CAS number: 52315-07-8). Concentrations referred to in this work are cypermethrin concentrations within the Barrage(R) formulation.
StressorTwoNote: ebrafish culture water with different pH (6, 7.5 and 9) was prepared using specific buffers (from Sigma-Aldrich(R)) for pH stabilization. For pH 6.0 the 2- (N-Morpholino) ethanesulfonic acid hydrate, 4- Morpholineethanesulfonic acid (MES) buffer was used (780 mg/L); for pH 7.5 the 3- (N-Morpholino) propanesulfonic acid, 4- Morpholinepropanesulfonic acid (MOPS) buffer was used (837 mg/L); and for pH 9.0 the 2- (Cyclohexylamino) ethanesulfonic acid (CHES) buffer was used (1560 mg/L). Buffers were diluted in fish culture water and pH adjusted with hydrochloric acid - HCl or sodium hydroxide - NaOH with the help of a portable multi-parameter device (Consort C5020). Barrage(R) was then added to the pH-corrected water. Barrage(R) (Zoetis-Fort Dodge, Campinas, SP, Brazil) is a concentrated, emulsifiable suspension containing 150 g/L of cypermethrin (α-cyano-3-phenoxybenzyl- 2,2-dimethyl-3- (2,2-dichlorovinyl) -cyclopropanecarboxylate, C22H19Cl2NO3, CAS number: 52315-07-8). Concentrations referred to in this work are cypermethrin concentrations within the Barrage(R) formulation.
StressorThreeNote: A stock solution of 1000 mg/L of nitrite was prepared from the dilution of sodium nitrite (NaNO2) in distilled water. This solution was used to prepare the nitrite concentrations 57, 98 and 167 mg/L of the salt, diluted in fish culture water. Water with corrected nitrite concentrations was used to dilute the Barrage(R) stock solution and attain the desired cypermethrin concentrations. To confirm nitrite concentrations of the prepared solutions, the nitrite content was determined using the NitriVer 3 Diazotization Method from Hach Co. (Loveland, CO) 8507. The HACH DR 2000 spectrometer was zeroed with deionized water. Twenty-five ml of the sample were added to the Nitriver 3 reagent and stirred. The formation of a pink complex indicated the presence of nitrite. The reaction time was 15 min. Blank and samples were read at 585 nm.

Authors: Wyatt, KH; Stevenson, RJ; Turetsky, MR
Title: The importance of nutrient co-limitation in regulating algal community composition, productivity and algal-derived DOC in an oligotrophic marsh in interior Alaska
StressorOneNote: In 2007, we randomly assigned each enclosure to one of three single-nutrient treatments (+N, +P or +Si) or a combination treatment (+N+P+Si), with four replicates each. We added nutrient amendments to enclosures every 4 days for 20 days beginning on 29 June 2007. The second phase of the experiment was conducted in June 2008 to determine which combination of nutrients was co-limiting. We deployed fresh Equisetum stems and randomly assigned each enclosure to one of three pair-wise nutrient treatments (+N+P, +N+Si, +P+Si) or +N+P+Si, with four replicates each. We added nutrient amendments to enclosures every 4 days for 20 days beginning on 17 June 2008. During each experiment (2007 and 2008), we used four enclosures without nutrients as a control treatment and, to evaluate container effects, designated four sampling sites within the wetland without enclosures or nutrient additions (open wetland).

StressorOneNote: The toxicities of the three insecticides were tested both separately as well as in binary and ternary combinations. Exposure concentrations were prepared by pipetting cal- culated concentrations of the stock solution into known volumes of test water to achieve desired concentrations. Exposure mixtures were prepared using a 1:1 single-ratio design by adding aliquots of nominally equivalent toxic units (TU) of the individual chemicals to the same con- tainer of test water. One TU was equivalent to the 96-h LC50 value of each chemical determined in the individual exposures. The same stock solutions were used for the preparation of all exposure solutions
StressorTwoNote: The toxicities of the three insecticides were tested both separately as well as in binary and ternary combinations. Authors: Li, XF; Zhou, QX; Luo, Y; Yang, G; Zhou, T
Title: Joint action and lethal levels of toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylene on midge (Chironomus plumosus) larvae
StressorOneNote: According to the pilot trial, the concentration of TEX in the single toxic experiment was set as the five graded series including toluene (28, 40, 56, 80, and 112 mgL-1), ethyl- benzene (15, 23, 35, 54, and 83 mgL-1), and xylene (26, 34, 45, 59, and 77 mgL-1), respectively. The mortalities of C. plumosus larvae after a 24- and a 48-h exposure were recorded to calculate the LC50 values with 95 % confidence limits using the probit analysis. In the binary mixture experi- ments, the mixtures comprised of six treatments at different concentration ratios including: (a) chemical A alone; (b) 4:1; (c) 3:2; (d) 1:1; (e) 2:3; (f) 1:4; and (g) chemical B alone. In the ternary mixture experiments, the proportions tested were divided into two treatments including: (a) 1:1:1 in toxic unit (TU) ratio and (b) 1:1:1 in the concentration ratio.

Authors: Iwasaki, Y; Cadmus, P; Clements, WH
Title: Comparison of different predictors of exposure for modeling impacts of metal mixtures on macroinvertebrates in stream microcosms
StressorOneNote: We used results of three microcosm experiments (Clements, 2004) in which macroinvertebrate communities from an unpolluted reference stream were exposed to Zn alone (>10-763 μg/L), Zn + Cd (Zn = >10-797 μg/L; Cd = >0.5-10 μg/L), and Zn + Cd + Cu (Zn = >10-992 μg/L; Cd = >0.5-10 μg/L; Cu = >5-85.5 μg/L). The concentrations of Cd and Cu were chosen to increase in proportion to that of Zn. Individual microcosm experiments involved 18 experimental streams which were randomly assigned to nine different metal levels for 10 days. Experiments were performed in August 1996, October 1997, and November 1999. A more complete description of microcosm experiments is available in Clements (2004). Cu and Cd were also tested individually so the largest interaction is three-way.
