Authors: Heier, LS; Teien, HC; Oughton, D; Tollefsen, KE; Olsvik, PA; Rosseland, BO; Lind, OC; Farmen, E; Skipperud, L; Salbu, B
Title: Sublethal effects in Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar) exposed to mixtures of copper, aluminium and gamma radiation
StressorOneNote: Low Cu - 10 µg/L (CulO) • Medium Cu - 40 µg/L (Cu40) • High Cu - 80 µg/L (Cu80)
StressorTwoNote: • Al - 250 µg/L (Al) • Al + medium Cu - 250 µg AI/L + 40 µg Cu/L (Al + Cu)
StressorThreeNote: 1.3. Irradiation protocol External y-radiation was provided by the UMB 60co gamma source (111 GBq) of which the field dosimetry (air kerma rates measured with an ionisation chamber) is traceable to the Norwegian Secondary Standard Dosimetry Laboratory. The radiation protocol delivered average dose rates (Fig. 1) (1.5, 0.35 and 0.09 mGy/h) to the fish at three defined distances from the source, resulting in total doses of 4, 17 and 70 mGy after 48 h of exposure. The geometric centre of the exposure box (WS x L40 x H20 cm) was used as reference point and was assumed to represent the best estimate of the dose. The maximum hypothetical variation in dose to fish was estimated to +/- 19% by calculating the increased dose rate in the unlikely case that the fishes would stay in the box area closest to the source. Controls (meta!, no radiation) were placed in the same room, outside the beam cone and shielded by lead. For the controls, the external (background) dose rate to the fish was determined to be approximately 0.2 µGy/h (Thermo Eberline FHT6020). 2.1.4. Fish exposure The experiments were approved by the National Anima! Research Authorities. Atlantic salmon of both sexes, weighing 47 +/- 16 g (n = 194), were transported (approx 15 min), from the hatchery at the Norwegian University ofLife Sciences (UMB) to the gamma source facility in 90 L black plastic tubs with Iid, and immediately exposed to Iake water upon arrival at the exposure Table 2 Overview over all the exposure groups, including metals and radiation. Water quality Radiation doses No gamma 4mGy 17mGy 70mGy Pre-exposure group ✓ (reference), hatchery Lake water, no meta! ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ Lake water + 10 µg/L Cu ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ Lake water + 40 µg/L Cu ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ Lake water + 80 µg/L Cu ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ Lake water + 250 µg/L Al ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ Lake water + 250 µg/L ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ Al + 40 µg/L Cu facilities. The fish used originated from Akvagen, Kyrks~terora, Norway. They were from different parentage. The fish in each experiment were collected from the same population at the hatchery, and physiological parameters were measured at each time point to reveal any potential differences due to time variation. Six fish were kept in each of the exposure boxes. All the fish within the same exposure group were exposed simultaneously in an experimental set-up previously described (Salbu et al., 2008) and depicted in Fig. 1. For each exposure group, water from the same tank (2300 L) was pumped on recirculation through all the boxes (2 L/min), each box housing 6 fish, in a flow through manner. To ensure high 0 2 and a low level of C( 1/2, the water was continuously pumped through a C02 stripper after passing each exposure tank before entering the water reservoir. The Ievel of 0 2 saturation was thus kept constant at 95-100%. The room temperature was held at approximately 10 °C, controlling the water temperature during all exposures. Six exposure experiments ( one for each water quality) were carried out, each for 48 h, over a period of 23 days (see Table 2 for details). During this period fish from the hatchery were sampled (n = 6) at different dates (n = 5) and act as a reference group (total 30 fish). 2.2. Sampling and sample treatment 2.2.1. In situ fractionation of water In situ fractionation was performed to characterise the size and charge distribution of Cu and Al in the exposure waters according to a protocol previously described by Teien et al. (2004). Size fractionation was performed using membrane filtration (0.45 µm, Millipore) and ultrafiltration using a hollow-fibre (Amicon) with nominal molecular cut-off mass of 10 kDa, while charge fractionation was utilised using ion exchange chromatography (Amberlite I

Authors: Naddy, RB; Cohen, AS; Stubblefield, WA
Title: THE INTERACTIVE TOXICITY OF CADMIUM, COPPER, AND ZINC TO CERIODAPHNIA DUBIA AND RAINBOW TROUT (ONCORHYNCHUS MYKISS)
StressorOneNote: CdCI2. The objectives of this research were to examine the effects of cadmium, copper, and zinc individually and in tri-metal mixtures in hard and soft waters using an equitoxic TU comparison approach. These 3 metals were chosen because they naturally occur together in the environment [18] and are relatively toxic individually. Organisms were exposed to the following series of treatments: 0.19, 0.37, 0.75, 1.5, 3, and 6 total mixture TUs of mixed metals (nominal values). Thus, the highest test treatment contained 2 TUs each of Cu, Cd, and Zn (total of 6 TUs). C. dubia in the first hard water mixture tests and in the soft water test were exposed to three different metal concentrations representing the same number of TUs used in the rainbow trout tests. Due to higher than expected mortality in the first C. dubia hard water test, TU treatments in the second and third tests were adjusted downward to 0.09, 0.19, 0.37, 0.75, and 1.5 total mixture TUs (nominal values).
StressorTwoNote: CuCI2

The diluted effluent prepared using Kauru River water contained at least 550 Escherichia coli cells per 100 mL (PetrifilmTM E. coli/Coliform Count Plate, 3M Microbiology Products, St Paul MN, USA), approximating the concentration in water deemed unsafe for recreational use (MfE/MoH, 2003).
StressorTwoNote: Light treatments (ambient versus reduced light) were applied throughout the experiment and monitored using HOBO  Temperature/Light Pendant Data Loggers (Onset Computer Corporation, Pocasset, MA, USA). The fabric hoods decreased incoming light by only 5% (Liess et al., 2009). Reduced light treatments were achieved by placing shade cloth (Nylex, Melbourne, Australia) on top of the fabric hood, resulting in a 73% reduction in mean light intensity (17066 lux versus 64479 lux) and a 6.6% reduction in mean water temperature (21.6 °C versus 20.2 °C) compared to channels covered with the fabric hoods only.
StressorThreeNote: The five antibiotic treatments (target concentrations in the stream channels) included a monensin-free control (without addition), monensin concentrations previously detected in agricultural streams (1 lg L  1; Lissemore et al., 2006), the recommended concentration of monensin administered to each dairy cow per day via reticulated drinking water in 2010 in New Zealand (300 lg L  1) and levels identified as toxicity thresholds for aquatic organisms (55 lg L  1 chronic exposure level and 550 lg L 1 acute exposure level; as reported by the Lilly Aquatic Exposure Guideline; LAEG; Elanco Rumensin Trough Treatment MSDS 2007).

We controlled the temperature within each water bath by using 1 or 2 aquarium heaters (Eheim J€ager 100W thermostat aquarium heater). For water baths in our most stable temperature regimes (low temperature range), we programmed a single heater to maintain a constant temperature. In water baths with more temperature variation, we programmed 2 aquarium heaters: the first to the lowest temperature for that treatment, and the second to the maximum temperature. The higher temperature heater was on a timer, resulting in a 12:12-h on:off cycle

Nominal concentrations of imidacloprid and terbuthylazine were 0 (no addition), 4 μg/L and 0 (no addition) and 3.5 μg/L respectively. All substances were distributed equally over the water surface level of each mesocosm to stimulate homogenization. Authors: Yang, XF; Xu, XP; Wei, XY; Wan, J; Zhang, Y
Title: Biomarker Effects in Carassius auratus Exposure to Ofloxacin, Sulfamethoxazole and Ibuprofen
Source: INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF ENVIRONMENTAL RESEARCH AND PUBLIC HEALTH
StressorOneNote: Ofloxacin, sulfamethoxazole and ibuprofen are three commonly used drugs which can be detected in aquatic environments. To assess their ecotoxicity, the effects of these three pharmaceuticals and their mixture on AChE (acetylcholinesterase) activity in the brain, and EROD (7-ethoxyresorufin-O-deethylase) and SOD (superoxide dismutase) activities in the liver of the freshwater crucian carp Carassius auratus were tested after exposure for 1, 2, 4 and 7 days. The pharmaceuticals were first dissolved in DMSO (dimethyl sulfoxide) and further diluted using dechlorinated tap water. Five concentrations each were prepared for ofloxacin (0.002, 0.01, 0.05, 0.25 and 1.25 mg/L), sulfamethoxazole (0.0008, 0.004, 0.02, 0.1 and 0.5 mg/L), ibuprofen (0.009, 0.045, 0.225, 1.125, 5.625 mg/L) and their mixture (M1-M5). For combined exposure, the three chemicals were mixed together in order of concentration. For example, M1 contained 0.002 mg/L ofloxacin, 0.0008 mg/L sulfamethoxazole and 0.009 mg/L ibuprofen. At the same time, a blank control and a solvent control with 0.05% DMSO were also prepared.
StressorTwoNote: Ofloxacin, sulfamethoxazole and ibuprofen are three commonly used drugs which can be detected in aquatic environments. The pharmaceuticals were first dissolved in DMSO (dimethyl sulfoxide) and further diluted using dechlorinated tap water. Five concentrations each were prepared for ofloxacin (0.002, 0.01, 0.05, 0.25 and 1.25 mg/L), sulfamethoxazole (0.0008, 0.004, 0.02, 0.1 and 0.5 mg/L), ibuprofen (0.009, 0.045, 0.225, 1.125, 5.625 mg/L) and their mixture (M1-M5). For combined exposure, the three chemicals were mixed together in order of concentration. For example, M1 contained 0.002 mg/L ofloxacin, 0.0008 mg/L sulfamethoxazole and 0.009 mg/L ibuprofen. At the same time, a blank control and a solvent control with 0.05% DMSO were also prepared.

Authors: Davis, SJ; hUallachain, DO; Mellander, PE; Matthaei, CD; Piggott, JJ; Kelly-Quinn, M
Title: Chronic nutrient inputs affect stream macroinvertebrate communities more than acute inputs: An experiment manipulating phosphorus, nitrogen and sediment
StressorOneNote: Manipulated three key agricultural stressors, phosphorus (ambient, chronic, acute), nitrogen (ambient, chronic, acute) and fine sediment (ambient, high), in 112 stream mesocosms (26 days colonisation, 18 days of manipulations). Treatments were randomly assigned to each mesocosm in a partial-factorial design with 8 replicates of each treatment combination. Nutrients (nitrate (NaNO3), phosphate (KH2PO4) or both) were continuously added using a fluid metering pump (BL10, Hanna Instruments, USA) to achieve mean concentrations of 8.04 +/- 0.512 mg l-1 DIN and 1.01 +/- 0.061 mg l-1 DRP (measured on day 1, 2, 6 and 13 of the experimental phase, n = 128) for chronic conditions. Concentrations of N and/or P were increased in acute channels to 16.11 +/- 0.415 mg l-1 DIN and 2.04 +/- 0.060 mg l-1 DRP (measured twice on day 6 and 13 (i.e. during the two acute pulses), n = 64) during two three-hour periods on days 6 and 13 of the manipulative phase. Following each pulse, concentrations were returned to chronic enrichment levels. Nutrient concentrations in ambient mesocosms were on average 0.99 +/- 0.116 mg l-1 DIN and 0.01 +/- 0.005 mg l-1 DRP (i.e. matching background stream concentrations, measured on day 1, 2, 6 and 13, n = 192). 240 ml of fine sediment added to mesocosms scheduled to receive sediment measured and averaged on the final day of sampling were 5.7 +/- 1.5% with a depth of 0.1 +/- 0.4 mm for ambient sediment treatments and 82.3 +/- 7.0% with a depth of 7.7 +/- 3.3 mm for high sediment treatments.
StressorTwoNote: Manipulated three key agricultural stressors, phosphorus (ambient, chronic, acute), nitrogen (ambient, chronic, acute) and fine sediment (ambient, high), in 112 stream mesocosms (26 days colonisation, 18 days of manipulations). StressorOneNote: Silver nitrate, a substitute for Ag+ released from silver nanoparticles (AgNO3, CAS No. 7761-88-8). Authors: Paquet-Walsh, A; Bertolo, A; Landry, C; Deschamps, L; Boily, M
Title: Interactive effects of neonicotinoids and natural ultraviolet radiation on yellow perch (Perca flavescens) larvae
StressorOneNote: Yellow perch larvae were exposed to three concentrations of TMX [thiamethoxam] (Exp-A, May 2015) and/or IMI [imidacloprid] (Exp-B, May 2016) crossed with three levels of natural UVR (no UV, UVA, UVAB) in a completely randomized block design. The concentrations of NEOCs (0, 8.33, and 23.32 ng L-1) were chosen to encompass the chronic aquatic life criterion. A fourth concentration of NEOCs (>6x; 132.8 ng L-1) was also tested under J-Roll(R) filters (i.e., in the absence of UVR) in order to increase the NEOC gradient and thus better assess the effects of TMX and IMI alone.
StressorTwoNote: Yellow perch larvae were exposed to three concentrations of TMX [thiamethoxam] (Exp-A, May 2015) and/or IMI [imidacloprid] (Exp-B, May 2016) crossed with three levels of natural UVR (no UV, UVA, UVAB) in a completely randomized block design. Authors: Jansen, LS; Pierre, S; Boughton, EH
Title: Interactions of fire, grazing and pasture management: Short-term and long-term responses of water quality to management regimes in subtropical isolated wetlands
SingleSpecies: juncus effusus subsp. solutus; eupatorium capillifolium; panicum hemitmon; persicaria punctata; paspalum notatum
StressorOneNote: Fenced or not (to exclude cattle grazing). The fencing was put in place in early 2007.
StressorTwoNote: Burned or not. Prescribed burns took place in February 2008 and 2011 on 20 randomly assigned wetlands and, in February 2013, twelve of 20 wetlands were burned and the other eight were burned in March 2014 due to weather conditions.
StressorThreeNote: Intensely managed and semi-native. Intensely managed pastures have been fertilized with both nitrogen and phosphorus for over 20 years before 1987 and continue to be fertilized with nitrogen every two years at approximately 56 kg/ha. Lime is also applied typically every 5 years at approximately 2200 kg/ha to increase pH. Semi-native pastures have no history of fertilization or liming. Intensely managed pastures have also been more heavily ditched than the semi-native pastures.

Authors: Salis, RK; Bruder, A; Piggott, JJ; Summerfield, TC; Matthaei, CD
Title: Multiple-stressor effects of dicyandiamide (DCD) and agricultural stressors on trait-based responses of stream benthic algal communities
StressorOneNote: DCD (eight treatment levels) was manipulated at the header-tank level. Target concentrations of DCD levels 1-7 were selected along a log-linear scale, with each level approximately 1.9 times the previous one. Level 0 (control) had a concentration of zero. Starting on Day 24, DCD was dissolved in 140-L holding tanks (refilled every 3-11 days) and pumped into header tanks using daily-recalibrated piston pumps (FMI CERAMPUMP(R) QBG, Fluid Metering Inc., Syosset, NY, U.S.A.). DCD concentrations in each treatment were measured on Days 24, 38, 41 and 44
StressorTwoNote: For sediment treatments, flow was briefly interrupted and 500 g of fine inorganic river sediment sourced from the floodplain of the Taieri River (mean particle size 0.2 mm; Matthaei et al., 2006) was added on Day 24 to 64 mesocosms. Sediment depth (average of four measurements per mesocosm) and cover (estimated visually) were measured on Days 34 and 44.
StressorThreeNote: For nutrient treatments, concentrated solutions of NaNO3 and KH2PO4 were applied to half the mesocosms with pressure-compensating drippers (RXLD2SC, RX Plastics, Ashburton, NZ). Dissolved nutrient levels were measured on Days 24, 38, 41 and 44 using standard methods (APHA, 1998). Concentrations in the 64 enriched mesocosms were 2814.7 +/- 40.8 μg L-1 DIN-N and 218.0 +/- 3.2 μg L-1 SRP-P (means +/- 1 SE; n = 256), reflecting high but realistic nutrient levels in New Zealand farmland streams

Following the method described by (Low-Decarie et al., 2015), mesocosms were bubbled for 15 min every 1.5 hr with ambient air in controls and air enriched to a concentration of 4,500 ppm CO2 in t reatments (Figure S1). Authors: Crane, K; Coughlan, NE; Cuthbert, RN; Dick, JTA; Kregting, L; Ricciardi, A; MacIsaac, HJ; Reid, N
Title: Friends of mine: An invasive freshwater mussel facilitates growth of invasive macrophytes and mediates their competitive interactions
StressorOneNote: Naturally occurring wild densities of D. polymorpha were estimated as living population 190 biomass (soft and hard tissues; wet weight g m-2) at ten locations in Lough Erne. For the 191 experimental treatments, three relative biomass categories were used: low (300g m-2), medium 192 (450g m-2) and high (600g m-2). Biomass estimates for D. polymorpha were similar to those 193 reported for Dreissena spp. inhabiting lakes in North America and Europe (Custer & Custer 194 1993; Cleven & Frenzel 1993; Karatayev et al. 2014; Ginn et al. 2017). In Lake Erie, for 195 example, the average biomass for mixed populations of D. polymorpha and a functionally 196 similar congener bivalve, the quagga mussel D. rostriformis bugensis, ranged from (mean +/- 197 SE) 55.4 +/- 11.8 to 588.8 +/- 94.4 g m-2 amongst different sites (Karatayev et al. 2014). However, 198 biomass is highly variable in relation to stage of invasion or age of population, and can be 199 impacted by changes to biotic and abiotic conditions (see Karatayev et al. 2014). 200 In addition, the biomass of non-living D. polymorpha shells was recorded with shells being 201 collected and scraped as clean as possible from each site (Table 1). Mean biomass of dead 202 9 shells was then calculated from across all sites, and a representative biomass was selected (100g 203 m-2). Mesocosms (1.5L: high-density polyethene) had a surface area of 88 cm2, thus mussel 204 treatments were scaled to replicate naturally occurring biomass i.e. zero mussels (representing 205 their absence), dead shells (0.88 g; an entire adult mussel 26.0 +/- 1 mm, scraped clean), Low 206 (2.64g; 1 adult mussel 26.0 +/- 1 mm), Medium (3.96g; 2 adult mussels 26.0 +/- 1 mm) and High 207 (5.28g; 3 adult mussels 26.0 +/- 1 mm) densities (Table 1). Mussels were placed directly on the 208 base of the mesocosms, but were free to reposition themselves within the mesocosm at all 209 times. Mesocosms did not contain any additional substrate.
StressorTwoNote: Elodea fragments were placed in the mesocosms which acted as a proxy for a shallow lake 211 ecosystem. As above, lake water obtained from Lough Erne was used to ensure plants had 212 sufficient nutrients for growth and D. polymorpha had sufficient seston to filter feed 213 (Vanderploeg 2017). Each mesocosm had two individual growing strands of Elodea; either 214 comprising a single species (i.e. two strands of E. canadensis or two strands of E. nuttallii), 215 representing the absence of interspecific competition; or both species together (i.e. one strand 216 of E. canadensis with one strand of E. nuttallii), representing the presence of interspecific 217 competition. These were combined in a factorial design with mussel treatments (zero, shells 218 only, low, medium and high density). Control mesocosms of water only were also used, i.e. no 219 plants or mussels added. Mesocosm water was exchanged for fresh, aerated lake water every 220 three days to ensure D. polymorpha had sufficient food, whilst air lines delivered oxygen and 221 water motion for the duration of the experiment. In total, the experiment was conducted over 222 twelve days, with four water cycles lasting three days each (see below). All experimental 223 groups were replicated in triplicate. Light of 30μmol photons m-2 s-1 was supplied by four 52 224 W Arcadia 1200mm Marine Stretch LED lamps under a 16:8 hour light: dark regime; 30μmol 225 photons was considered sufficient for photosynthesis (Mielecki & Pieczynska 2005). All waste 226 invasive plant material was destroyed after the experiment by autoclaving.
StressorThreeNote: Elodea fragments were placed in the mesocosms which acted as a proxy for a shallow lake 211 ecosystem. Authors: Pinto, TJD; Freitas, JS; Moreira, RA; da Silva, LCM; Yoshii, MPC; Lopes, LFD; Goulart, BV; Vanderlei, MR; Athayde, DB; Fraga, PD; Ogura, AP; Schiesari, L; Montagner, CC; Daam, MA; Espindola, ELG
Title: Functional responses of Hyalella meinerti after exposure to environmentally realistic concentrations of 2,4-D, fipronil, and vinasse (individually and in mixture)
StressorOneNote: Mesocosms were randomly allocated to six different treatments with three replicates each: (1) untreated control (C); (2) herbicide DMA(R) 806 BR (a.s. 2,4-D) (D); (3) insecticide Regent(R) 800 W G (a.s. fipronil) (F); (4) mixture of the herbicide and insecticide (M); (5) sugarcane vinasse (V), and (6) mixture of fipronil, 2,4-D and vinasse (MV). To calculate the application dose of the pesticides, direct (100 %) overspray was simulated. the recommended dose and top diameter of the tanks (1.75 m) were considered, resulting in an application dose of 1 mL DMA (670 mg 2,4-D - acid equivalent) and 120 mg Regent (96 mg fipronil). The expected nominal concentrations were 447 μg 2,4-D/L and 64 μg fipronil/L. Application and hence test concentrations of the pesticides used in isolated conditions were the same as those used in the mixture treatments. volume of vinasse applied was calculated based on doses (liters per hectare); so 20 L of vinasse was applied in each mesocosm receiving vinasse treatment, corresponding to an expected concentration of 1.3 % (V/V).
StressorTwoNote: Mesocosms were randomly allocated to six different treatments with three replicates each: (1) untreated control (C); (2) herbicide DMA(R) 806 BR (a.s. 2,4-D) (D); (3) insecticide Regent(R) 800 W G (a.s. fipronil) (F); (4) mixture of the herbicide and insecticide (M); (5) sugarcane vinasse (V), and (6) mixture of fipronil, 2,4-D and vinasse (MV). Authors: Pinto, TJD; Freitas, JS; Moreira, RA; da Silva, LCM; Yoshii, MPC; Lopes, LFD; Goulart, BV; Vanderlei, MR; Athayde, DB; Fraga, PD; Ogura, AP; Schiesari, L; Montagner, CC; Daam, MA; Espindola, ELG
Title: Functional responses of Hyalella meinerti after exposure to environmentally realistic concentrations of 2,4-D, fipronil, and vinasse (individually and in mixture)
StressorOneNote: Mesocosms were randomly allocated to six different treatments with three replicates each: (1) untreated control (C); (2) herbicide DMA(R) 806 BR (a.s. 2,4-D) (D); (3) insecticide Regent(R) 800 W G (a.s. fipronil) (F); (4) mixture of the herbicide and insecticide (M); (5) sugarcane vinasse (V), and (6) mixture of fipronil, 2,4-D and vinasse (MV). To calculate the application dose of the pesticides, direct (100 %) overspray was simulated. the recommended dose and top diameter of the tanks (1.75 m) were considered, resulting in an application dose of 1 mL DMA (670 mg 2,4-D - acid equivalent) and 120 mg Regent (96 mg fipronil). For in situ testing, adult amphipods were deployed in the mesocosms two hours before the contamination in 400 mL circular plastic cages with two opening (+/- 40 cm2 each) covered with a 45 μm net. Two cages were placed in each mesocosm containing eight males and seven females each, to stimulate the competition between males. The cages were placed at the bottom of the mesocosms.

Authors: Yan, ZW; Wang, QY; Li, Y; Wu, L; Wang, JN; Xing, B; Yu, D; Wang, LG; Liu, CH
Title: Combined effects of warming and nutrient enrichment on water properties, growth, reproductive strategies and nutrient stoichiometry of Potamogeton crispus
StressorOneNote: A three-factorial design, with the direction of eutrophication and climate warming, the three factors in the experiment are temperature, nitrogen addition and phosphorus addition, included seven levels of nutrient treatment: (i) control, 12 tanks with Liangzi Lake water (N0P0, TN: 0.81 mg L􀀀 1, TP: 0.04 mg L􀀀 1); (ii) addition of nitrogen (NaNO3), 12 tanks with moderate N concentrations (N1P0, TN: 3 mg L􀀀 1, TP: 0.04 mg L􀀀 1) and 12 tanks with high N concentrations (N2P0, TN: 8 mg L􀀀 1, TP: 0.04 mg L􀀀 1); (iii) addition of phosphorus (NaH2PO4), 12 tanks with moderate P concentrations (N0P1, TN: 0.81 mg L􀀀 1, TP: 0.2 mg L􀀀 1) and 12 tanks with high P concentrations (N0P2, TN: 0.81 mg L􀀀 1, TP: 0.4 mg L􀀀 1); (iv) addition of nitrogen and phosphorus, 12 tanks with moderate nutrient concentrations (N1P1, TN: 3 mg L􀀀 1, TP: 0.2 mg L􀀀 1) and 12 tanks with high nutrient concentrations (N2P2, TN: 8 mg L􀀀 1, TP: 0.4 mg L􀀀 1). Half of the tanks with each nutrient treatment were in the greenhouse, and half of the tanks were outdoors. The temperature in the greenhouse was 2.65 +/- 0.07 ℃ higher than that outdoor (Fig. S1). All 84 P. crispus turions were randomly assigned to the 84 tanks, and each treatment had six replicates. The treatments were arranged in a random order. To maintain the set water volume, deionized water was added to replenish water lost by transpiration every week. Rain covers stood above the greenhouse so that rainwater could not run into the tanks. The photosynthetically active radiation in and out of the greenhouse was 841.25-2451.25 (μmol⋅s􀀀 1 m􀀀 2) and 903.58-2799.00 (μmol⋅s􀀀 1 m􀀀 2) respectively (Table S1). In addition, nutrient solutions should be added every two weeks to maintain nutrient concentration.

Authors: Macaulay, SJ; Hageman, KJ; Piggott, JJ; Juvigny-Khenafou, NPD; Matthaei, CD
Title: Warming and imidacloprid pulses determine macroinvertebrate community dynamics in experimental streams
SingleSpecies: potamopyrgus antipodarum; deleatidium spp.; chydorus spp.; oxyethira albiceps
StressorOneNote: Heating began on Day 0 and was applied continuously for 24 days, with an average heating treatment of 3.0 +/- 0.86°C (SD) above ambient (measured at 5- minute intervals from Days 0-24 using HOBO(R) Pendant Temperature/Light Data Loggers; Onset Computer Corporation). This corresponds to the projected increase in mean temperatures for New Zealand by 2090 (2081-2100, relative to 1986-2005) under the high emissions scenario (Representative concentration pathway 8.5; IPCC, 2014).
StressorTwoNote: Three 48-hour pulses applied 10 days apart at 0, 0.1, 0.48 and 4.61 microgams per litre in the commercial formulation Confidor, using individually attached pressure compensating drippers (model RXLD2SC; RX Plastics, New Zealand) at a rate of 2 L/hour from three 13- mm pipes. Concentrated imidacloprid solutions were continuously injected from adjacent 240- L supply barrels into each pipe by fluid- metering pumps (FMI CERAMPUMP(R) Lab Pump Model QBG, Fluid Metering Inc., Syosset, USA) during each pesticide pulse.
StressorThreeNote: Reduced flow velocity from 20.5 cm/s to 1.4 cm/s. Flow velocity was manipulated during the colonisation period, beginning 21 days before the start of the heating and imidacloprid- pulse manipulations (beginning on Day 0), by installing an inflow jet to half of the channels to increase flow velocity (fast- flow treatment) and altering the inflow angle to the other half of the channels (with no jet) to reduce velocity (slow- flow treatment).

StressorOneNote: We carried out two successive manipulative experiments at different scales: first, a 22-d indoor microcosm experiment under controlled conditions with and without air supply to analyze a possible impact of changes in dissolved oxygen on the survival of mussels exposed to glyphosate, 2,4-D and their mixture; and then, an 18-d outdoor mesocosm experiment without air supply to compare the effect of both herbicides and their mixture on mussel's survival. Title: Reproducibility of binary-mixture toxicity studies
StressorOneNote: The dose-response surfaces of the binary herbicide mixtures were obtained using a classical ray design [5]. The ray design consists of dose-response curves of the two individual herbicides tested alone and a number of dose-response curves of the herbicides mixed at predefined mixture ratios. The mixture ratios were chosen with the aim of obtaining a contribution to the overall effect of the two herbicides of 100:0, 75:25, 50: 50, 25:75, and 0:100 for five-mixture-ratio experiments and of 100:0, 83:17, 67:33, 50:50, 33:67, 83:17, and 0:100 for seven-mixture-ratio experiments. The concentrations of each pesticide needed to obtain these effect-based mixture ratios were determined on the basis of the ED50s or EC50s of previous experiments. The number of doses and replications within the same dose varied among test systems.

Authors: Staley, ZR; Rohr, JR; Harwood, VJ
Title: The effect of agrochemicals on indicator bacteria densities in outdoor mesocosms
StressorOneNote: Tanks were arranged in a randomized block design with four replicates of each of 16 treatments. There were two control treatments, with addition of only 50 ml of water or acetone (used as a solvent for all agrochemicals). Tanks in the remaining 14 treatments received agrochemicals. Our representative agrochemicals were the herbicide atrazine, the insecticide malathion, the fungicide chlorothalonil and inorganic fertilizer (sodium nitrate and sodium phosphate). All pesticides were technical grade (purity > 98%, Chemservice, West Chester, PA). Six of the agrochemical treatments were pair-wise combinations of the agrochemicals at their EECs calculated using the Environmental Protection Agency's GENEEC v2 software. Fertilizer was added at an EEC of 220 µg l-1 P: 4675 µg l-1 N, a concentration found commonly in a pond survey (Chase, 2003). The remaining eight treatments were each agrochemical alone, either at its EEC (1* EEC) or at double its EEC (2* EEC). The 2* EEC treatments were incorporated in an effort to control for the fact that mixtures had twice the concentration of agrochemicals as the single-chemical treatments. Lone agrochemicals and agrochemical mixtures were dissolved in 50 ml of acetone so that each agrochemical tank received the same amount of acetone. To quantify actual concentrations, pooled samples from each lone pesticide treatment were analysed by the Mississippi State Chemical Laboratory (Starkville, MS) and samples from each lone fertilizer treatment were analysed by the Hillsborough County Water Resource Services Environmental Laboratory (Tampa, FL).

The remaining eight treatments were each agrochemical alone, either at its EEC (1* EEC) or at double its EEC (2* EEC). The 2* EEC treatments were incorporated in an effort to control for the fact that mixtures had twice the concentration of agrochemicals as the single-chemical treatments. Lone agrochemicals and agrochemical mixtures were dissolved in 50 ml of acetone so that each agrochemical tank received the same amount of acetone. To quantify actual concentrations, pooled samples from each lone pesticide treatment were analysed by the Mississippi State Chemical Laboratory (Starkville, MS) and samples from each lone fertilizer treatment were analysed by the Hillsborough County Water Resource Services Environmental Laboratory (Tampa, FL).
StressorFourNote: Tanks were arranged in a randomized block design with four replicates of each of 16 treatments. There were two control treatments, with addition of only 50 ml of water or acetone (used as a solvent for all agrochemicals). Tanks in the remaining 14 treatments received agrochemicals. Our representative agrochemicals were the herbicide atrazine, the insecticide malathion, the fungicide chlorothalonil and inorganic fertilizer (sodium nitrate and sodium phosphate). All pesticides were technical grade (purity > 98%, Chemservice, West Chester, PA). Six of the agrochemical treatments were pair-wise combinations of the agrochemicals at their EECs calculated using the Environmental Protection Agency's GENEEC v2 software. Fertilizer was added at an EEC of 220 µg l-1 P: 4675 µg l-1 N, a concentration found commonly in a pond survey (Chase, 2003). The remaining eight treatments were each agrochemical alone, either at its EEC (1* EEC) or at double its EEC (2* EEC). The 2* EEC treatments were incorporated in an effort to control for the fact that mixtures had twice the concentration of agrochemicals as the single-chemical treatments. Lone agrochemicals and agrochemical mixtures were dissolved in 50 ml of acetone so that each agrochemical tank received the same amount of acetone. To quantify actual concentrations, pooled samples from each lone pesticide treatment were analysed by the Mississippi State Chemical Laboratory (Starkville, MS) and samples from each lone fertilizer treatment were analysed by the Hillsborough County Water Resource Services Environmental Laboratory (Tampa, FL).

StressorOneNote: To standardise relative agrochemical exposure concentrations, we used US EPA GENEEC v2 software (US EPA, Washington, DC, USA), which uses the physicochemical properties of agrochemicals in conjunction with manufacturer application recommendations to estimate the peak exposure concentration (EEC) for each biocide (parameters reported in Table S5). Experimental treatments consisted of four agrochemicals in isolation at one of two concentrations (19 and 29 EEC; fertiliser: nitrogen, 19 = 4400 lg/L, phosphorus, 19 = 440 lg/L; fungicide: chlorothalonil, EEC = 164 lg/L; herbicide: atrazine, EEC = 102 lg/L; insecticide: malathion, EEC = 101 lg/L), all six possible pairwise mixtures of agrochemicals (19 EEC of each chemical) and water and solvent (50 mg/L acetone) controls. Total nitrogen and phosphorus concentrations were similar to those found in high productivity ponds reported by Chase (2003). Nitrogen and phosphorus concentrations in control tanks were 370 and 60 lg/L, respectively, but we did not determine which was the limiting nutrient.

Authors: Patra, RW; Chapman, JC; Lim, RP; Gehrke, PC; Sunderam, RM
Title: Interactions between water temperature and contaminant toxicity to freshwater fish
SingleSpecies: bidyanus bidyanus; oncorhynchus mykiss; melanotaenia duboulayi
StressorOneNote: Fish were kept in holding tanks and transferred to 60-L glass aquaria for acclimation at different test temperatures. Silver perch, rainbowfish, and western carp gudgeon were initially held at 20 °C, whereas rainbow trout were held at 10 °C. Fish were brought to acclimation temperatures gradually at a rate never exceeding 1 °C per day and were then maintained in the dilution water at these temperatures for at least 15 d before use. Toxicity tests were conducted in a flow-through system at 15 °C, 20 °C, 25 °C, 30 °C, and 35 °C for warm water species (silver perch, rainbowfish, and western carp gudgeon), and at 5 °C, 10 °C, 15 °C, 20 °C, and 25 °C for rainbow trout, in recognition of its cold water status. Desired concentrations of chemicals reaching the test chambers were obtained by adjusting both the flow rates of chemicals and the dilution water. Stock solutions of chemicals were stored in 10-L glass jars and delivered to the test chambers by 8-channel Gilson Minipuls 3 peristaltic pumps at the rate required to produce the nominated concentrations.  Five peristaltic pumps and 35 test tanks were used for each test. Concentrations of chemicals used in the tests were based on range-finding acute tests over a period of 96 h at various temperatures using acute toxicity, expressed as the 96-h median effective concentration (EC50) of each chemical. The 96-h lethal concentration at 50% values for endosulfan, chlorpyrifos, and phenol for this fish were 1.3 +/- 0.25 μg L-1, 17 +/- 6 μg L-1, and 14 +/- 4 mg L-1, respectively

Title: Mixture toxicity of s-triazines to Lemna minor under conditions of simultaneous and sequential exposure
StressorOneNote: Therefore, we analysed the effects of 4 individual s-triazines (atrazine, prometon, prometryn and ametryn) and a mixture of these on the growth of the limnic vascular plant Lemna minor. The overall mixture toxicity of the 4-compound s-triazine mixture could be precisely predicted by Concentration Addition

The latter differed in peak concentrations and pulse frequencies (Fig. S2b; high pulse: 3.5 +/- 0.2 mg L-1; low pulse: 2.2 +/- 0.1 mg L-1 [daily means +/- 1 SE n = 32] followed by exponential decreases [k = 0.25] during 11 and 5 days, respectively). These peaks were chosen according to DCD concentrations measured after rainfall events in first-order streams draining a dairy farm in New Zealand

Fine sediment depth (four measurements per mesocosm averaged) and sediment cover (estimated visually) were measured on Day 46. Authors: Yuan, WK; Zhou, YF; Chen, YL; Liu, XN; Wang, J
Title: Toxicological effects of microplastics and heavy metals on the Daphnia magna
StressorOneNote: In this study, the adsorption behaviors of four typical heavy metal ions (Pb2+, Cu2+, Cd2+, and Ni2+) on two sizes of polystyrene MPs (10 μm and 50 μm) were investigated based on batch experiments, and  combined effects of heavy metals and MPs were assessed using Daphnia magna as model. Based on the single toxicity results, combined toxicity bioassay was carried out under same conditions. According to our pre-experiments, different mixtures of MPs (0, 0.01, 0.1, 1, 10, 100, 500, and 1000 mg/L) and heavy metals (the constant EC50 concentrations) in AFW were established as the test solutions (Table S1). Interactions tested were between microplastic and each metal individually.

Authors: Lewis, JL; Agostini, G; Jones, DK; Relyea, RA
Title: Cascading effects of insecticides and road salt on wetland communities
StressorOneNote: To evaluate the potentially interactive effects of pesticides and road salt, we used a factorial combination of four insecticides (malathion, chlorpyrifos, cypermethrin, permethrin) at two concentrations (low, high) to create eight pesticide treatments (Table S1). We then added a vehicle control (ethanol) and no-pesticide control (water) to the experimental treatments. These 10 treatments were crossed with three nominal road salt (NaCl) concentrations: low salt (44 mg Cl-/L), medium salt (160 mg Cl-/L), and high salt (1693 mg Cl-/L). The 30 treatment combinations were replicated four times for a total of 120 experimental units.

Authors: Scholz, NL; Truelove, NK; Labenia, JS; Baldwin, DH; Collier, TK
Title: Dose-additive inhibition of chinook salmon acetylcholinesterase activity by mixtures of organophosphate and carbamate insecticides
StressorOneNote: To determine the inhibitory effects of insecticides on chinook olfactory cholinesterase, tissue extracts were treated with two carbamates (carbaryl and carbofuran) and the oxon metabolites of three organophosphates (chlorpyrifos-oxon, diazinon-O-analog, and malaoxon). For the organophosphates, oxon derivatives were used because these metabolites, and not their respective parent compounds (chlorpyrifos, diazinon, and malathion), are primarily responsible for cholinesterase inhibition in vertebrates [33]. For clarity, we subsequently refer to the oxon derivatives as chlorpyrifos-oxon, diazinon-oxon, and malathion-oxon. As with the pharmacological inhibitors, pesticides were applied (alone or in binary combinations) during the incubation step of the Ellman assay. Nominal treatment concentrations were as follows: carbaryl (0-23,560 μg/L, n = 18 concentrations); carbofuran (0-5,890 μg/L, n = 20); chlorpyrifos-oxon (0-236 μg/L, n = 12); diazinon-oxon (0-10,720 μg/L, n = 12); malathion-oxon (0-104 μg/L, n = 12). Analytical grade pesticides and pesticide metabolites were purchased from Chem Services (West Chester, PA, USA).
StressorTwoNote: To determine the inhibitory effects of insecticides on chinook olfactory cholinesterase, tissue extracts were treated with two carbamates (carbaryl and carbofuran) and the oxon metabolites of three organophosphates (chlorpyrifos-oxon, diazinon-O-analog, and malaoxon). For the organophosphates, oxon derivatives were used because these metabolites, and not their respective parent compounds (chlorpyrifos, diazinon, and malathion), are primarily responsible for cholinesterase inhibition in vertebrates [33]. For clarity, we subsequently refer to the oxon derivatives as chlorpyrifos-oxon, diazinon-oxon, and malathion-oxon. As with the pharmacological inhibitors, pesticides were applied (alone or in binary combinations) during the incubation step of the Ellman assay. Nominal treatment concentrations were as follows: carbaryl (0-23,560 μg/L, n = 18 concentrations); carbofuran (0-5,890 μg/L, n = 20); chlorpyrifos-oxon (0-236 μg/L, n = 12); diazinon-oxon (0-10,720 μg/L, n = 12); malathion-oxon (0-104 μg/L, n = 12). Analytical grade pesticides and pesticide metabolites were purchased from Chem Services (West Chester, PA, USA).

Authors: Madureira, TV; Rocha, MJ; Cruzeiro, C; Galante, MH; Monteiro, RAF; Rocha, E
Title: The toxicity potential of pharmaceuticals found in the Douro River estuary (Portugal): Assessing impacts on gonadal maturation with a histopathological and stereological study of zebrafish ovary and testis after sub-acute exposures
StressorOneNote: Effects of non-steroidal pharmaceuticals in the gonadal maturation of zebrafish (Danio rerio) were evaluated by histopathological and stereological analyses after 21 days of exposure. Carbamazepine, fenofibric acid, propranolol, sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim were selected, considering their detection in the Douro estuary (Portugal). Exposures were performed with single compounds and mixtures, the exposure concentrations including environmental levels. Zebrafish were exposed to 0.01% (v/v) of the vehicle ethanol (Control II) and to either one of two distinct mixtures of all pharmaceuticals, which were designated as MXA and MXB. The MXB corresponded to the mixture of the compounds in the same concentrations as in experiment I (artificially high, CBZ (1780 μg/L), FA (703 μg/L), PHO (31.8 μg/L), SMX (533 μg/L) or TMP (157 μg/L). The tested nominal concentrations correspond to 10,000 times the maximum concentrations found for each compound in the reference ecosystem, the Douro River estuary. The MXA situation simulated the maximum environmental concentrations of those pharmaceuticals as reported by Madureira et al., 2010, being constituted by the following nominal concentrations: 178 ng/L of CBZ, 70.3 ng/L of FA, 3.18 ng/L of PHO, 53.3 ng/L of SMX and 15.7 ng/L of TMP. In this experiment, six control and seven replicates of each mixture group were conducted, in similar conditions as those described for experiment I (N = 12 animals/sex/control group and N = 14 animals/sex/mixture group).

Authors: Wang, YH; Yang, GL; Dai, DJ; Xu, ZL; Cai, LM; Wang, Q; Yu, YJ
Title: Individual and mixture effects of five agricultural pesticides on zebrafish (Danio rerio) larvae
StressorOneNote: Equivalent concentration test: The concentrations of each individual pesticide in the mixture components were then sequentially doubled (1*, 2*, 4*, 8*, 16*, 32*) to give the six concentrations tested. The concentration of binary, ternary, quaternary, and quinquenary mixtures was kept constant (1:1, 1:1:1, 1:1:1:1, or 1:1:1:1:1), while the total concentration of the mixture systematically varied. Equitoxic ratio test: Equitoxic ratio mixture toxicity was also tested. In order to assess the interaction of equitoxic mixtures, the zebrafish lar- vae were treated with serial dilutions of each pesticide with a fixed equitoxic constant mixture ratio (the same effect came from each individual pesticide), based on the measured indi- vidual LC50 values. Six dilutions (with a serial dilution factor of 2) of each pesticide with their binary, ternary, quaternary, and quinquenary mixtures were tested. Complete concentration-response relationships could be experimentally obtained by varying the total concentration of each mixture and keeping all the abovementioned ratios in the mixtures constant.

In order to assess the interaction of equitoxic mixtures, the zebrafish lar- vae were treated with serial dilutions of each pesticide with a fixed equitoxic constant mixture ratio (the same effect came from each individual pesticide), based on the measured indi- vidual LC50 values. Six dilutions (with a serial dilution factor of 2) of each pesticide with their binary, ternary, quaternary, and quinquenary mixtures were tested. Complete concentration-response relationships could be experimentally obtained by varying the total concentration of each mixture and keeping all the abovementioned ratios in the mixtures constant.
StressorFiveNote: Equivalent concentration test: The concentrations of each individual pesticide in the mixture components were then sequentially doubled (1*, 2*, 4*, 8*, 16*, 32*) to give the six concentrations tested. The concentration of binary, ternary, quaternary, and quinquenary mixtures was kept constant (1:1, 1:1:1, 1:1:1:1, or 1:1:1:1:1), while the total concentration of the mixture systematically varied. Equitoxic ratio test: Equitoxic ratio mixture toxicity was also tested. In order to assess the interaction of equitoxic mixtures, the zebrafish lar- vae were treated with serial dilutions of each pesticide with a fixed equitoxic constant mixture ratio (the same effect came from each individual pesticide), based on the measured indi- vidual LC50 values. Six dilutions (with a serial dilution factor of 2) of each pesticide with their binary, ternary, quaternary, and quinquenary mixtures were tested. Complete concentration-response relationships could be experimentally obtained by varying the total concentration of each mixture and keeping all the abovementioned ratios in the mixtures constant.

Authors: Thrupp, TJ; Runnalls, TJ; Scholze, M; Kugathas, S; Kortenkamp, A; Sumpter, JP
Title: The consequences of exposure to mixtures of chemicals: Something from 'nothing' and 'a lot froma little' when fish are exposed to steroid hormones
StressorOneNote: Concentration-response curveswere generated by the single chemical experiments, some of which have been reported previously (EE2 and levonorgestrel: Runnalls et al., 2015; desogestrel: Runnalls et al., 2013). These single chemical concentration-response curves were used to design a five chemical mixture experiment. A five component mixture was designed based on the concentration responses of the individual compounds. A fixed equipotent mixture ratio was used, proportional to the concentration of each compound that produced a 10% effect level, or EC10 (interpreted from the single concentration response data). Three mixture concentrations were chosen in order to assess mixture effects at a range of concentrations.

Authors: Yang, GL; Lv, L; Di, SS; Li, XF; Weng, HB; Wang, XQ; Wang, YH
Title: Combined toxic impacts of thiamethoxam and four pesticides on the rare minnow (Gobiocypris rarus)
StressorOneNote: For the three four-component combinations of thiamethoxam-chlorpyrifos-beta-cypermethrin-tetraconazole, thiamethoxam-chlorpyrifos-beta-cypermethrin-azoxystrobin, and thiamethoxam-beta-cypermethrin-tetraconazole-azoxystrobin, and one five-component combination of thiamethoxam-chlorpyrifos-beta-cypermethrin-tetraconazole-azoxystrobin, their additive indexes ranged from 1.18 to 5.46 after treatment for 48 h and from 1.29 to 5.70 after treatment for 96 h, displaying synergetic responses. Furthermore, their additive indexes were elevated along with the prolongation of treatment time (except for the four-component combination of thiamethoxam-chlorpyrifos-beta-cypermethrin-tetraconazole). However, the four-component combination of thiamethoxam-chlorpyrifos-tetraconazole-azoxystrobin exhibited additive indexes of - 0.19 and - 0.41 after treatment for 48 h and 96 h, respectively, indicating additive and antagonistic responses, respectively (Fig. 1C).

These are toxicity tests so many concentrations are used (same for combinations: mixtures were prepared by combining individual stock solutions in a composition ratio 1:1.). Results given as toxicity capacity. For the purposes of quantifying interactions, it is essentially presense or absence of each chemical (i.e. toxicity level and how it varys with Irgarol alone and Irgarol combined with individual other biocides). Only Irgarol-other biocide combinations are done (i.e. Iragarol is in all stressor pairs).

These are toxicity tests so many concentrations are used (same for combinations: mixtures were prepared by combining individual stock solutions in a composition ratio 1:1.). Results given as toxicity capacity. For the purposes of quantifying interactions, it is essentially presense or absence of each chemical (i.e. toxicity level and how it varys with Irgarol alone and Irgarol combined with individual other biocides). Only Irgarol-other biocide combinations are done (i.e. Iragarol is in all stressor pairs).

Authors: Qin, LT; Liu, M; Zhang, X; Mo, LY; Zeng, HH; Liang, YP
Title: Concentration Addition, Independent Action, and Quantitative Structure-Activity Relationships for Chemical Mixture Toxicities of the Disinfection By products of Haloacetic Acids on the Green Alga Raphidocelis subcapitata
StressorOneNote: All binary mixtures (15 combinations) each at 5 concentrations. Testing was performed on the green alga R. subcapitata obtained from the Freshwater Algae Culture Collection at the Institute of Hydrobiology (FACHB collection, no. FACHB-271) in China by using the specific growth rate as an endpoint. The green algae were cultured in the BG11 culture medium recommended by the FACHB collection. The BG11 medium is composed of 10 mL of 150.00 g/L NaNO3, 10 mL of 4.00 g/L K2HPO4, 10 mL of 7.50 g/L MgSO4 * 7H2O, 10 mL of 3.60 g/L CaCl2 * 2H2O, 10 mL of 0.60 g/L citric acid, 10 mL of 0.60 g/L ferric ammonium citrate, 10 mL of 0.10 g/L EDTANa2,10mLof 2.00 g/LNa2CO3, and 1 mL of A5 solution, where A5 solution consists of 2.86 g/LH3BO3, 1.86 g/L MnCl2 * 4H2O, 0.22 g/L ZnSO4 * 7H2O, 0.39 g/LNa2MoO4 * 2H2O, 0.08 g/L CuSO4 * 5H2O, and 0.05 g/L Co(NO3)2 * 6H2O. The culture was performed at 22 +/- 1 °C and 2500 to 3000 lux light conditions. The treatment and control groups were tested under the conditions of log-phase growth for 96 h. The optical density (OD) of the control as a function of time is shown in Supplemental Data, Figure S1

Authors: Rios-Arana, JV; Walsh, EJ; Ortiz, M
Title: Interaction effects of multi-metal solutions (As, Cr, Cu, Ni, Pb and Zn) on life history traits in the rotifer Plationus patulus
Source: JOURNAL OF ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE AND HEALTH PART A-TOXIC/HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES & ENVIRONMENTAL ENGINEERING
StressorOneNote: Based on a previous survey of As and heavy metals in the Rio Bravo in the El Paso-Juarez area, two concentrations of Cr, Cu, Ni, and three of As, Pb, and Zn were selected to evaluate their effects on P. patulus population dynamics. Thirty-seven treatments, including two controls, 15 single exposure treatments and 20 combinations of the six elements, were tested; Arsenic and metal stock solutions of 100 mg/L were prepared by dissolving appropriate amounts of arsenic (V) oxide, chromium (III) nitrate, nickel (II) nitrate, cupric sulfate, lead nitrate, and zinc sulfate in distilled water

Authors: Hsieh, SH; Tsai, KP; Chen, CY
Title: The combined toxic effects of nonpolar narcotic chemicals to Pseudokirchneriella subcapitata
StressorOneNote: Mixture toxicity tests were conducted at equitoxic ratio, which means that dz1=EC501TH : dz1=EC502TH  1/4 1 : 1. Mixtures of the two toxicants with different sums of toxic units (say, 4, 2, 1, 0.5, 0.25, etc.) were tested. Based on the observed inhibition rates, M and its 95% CI at 50% response could be determined using probit analysis. For instance, if the toxicant concentration causing 50% response was found to be 2 toxic units, Z1 and Z2 were equal to 1  EC501 and 1  EC502, respectively. Thirteen binary mixtures were tested including aromatic mixtures, aliphatic mixtures and aromatic-aliphatic mixtures. However, eventually, no distinct difference in terms of the combined toxic effects was found among the three types of mixtures. Three aromatic chemicals and seven aliphatic compounds were tested in this study. All chemicals used were of 99% purity (reagent grade) except for benzene (95% purity). Tests were performed in triplicate. Stock solutions of toxicants were prepared in foil-wrapped glass containers. Before commencing the experiment, stock solution was freshly prepared and its concentration was analyzed using a HPLC analyzer. The analytical results were used to define the nominal concentrations for various treatments. Cell density was measured by electronic particle counting (Coulter Multisizer).

Authors: Mount, DR; Erickson, RJ; Forsman, BB; Highland, TL; Hockett, JR; Hoff, DJ; Jenson, CT; Norberg-King, TJ
Title: Chronic toxicity of major ion salts and their mixtures to Ceriodaphnia dubia
StressorOneNote: Thirteen experiments were conducted, each consisting of 2 to 5 chronic toxicity tests structured to evaluate different aspects of major ion toxicity (Table 1) using an experimental approach similar to that in previous acute testing with C. dubia (Mount et al. 2016; Erickson et al. 2017). Individual experiments were structured to evaluate 1) the effect of renewing solutions only on days 3 and 5, rather than daily (experiment 1); 2) the chronic toxicity of individual major ion salts (experiments 1-3); 3) how Ca concentration affects the toxicity of NaCl and MgCl2 (experiments 4 and 5); and 4) the interactive chronic toxicity of binary mixtures of major ion salts (experiments 6-12). A last experiment (13) compared the toxicity of NaCl and MgCl2 to that of mannitol, Na gluconate, and Mg gluconate. Levels estimated from figures

Authors: Flaherty, CM; Dodson, SI
Title: Effects of pharmaceuticals on Daphnia survival, growth, and reproduction
StressorOneNote: Pharmaceutical mixtures were chosen based on individual therapeutic use and mode of action. To simulate simultaneous environmental exposure to pharmaceuticals from different classes, we exposed D. magna to a mixture of a cholesterol drug metabolite, clofibric acid (10 or 100 μg/l), and an antidepressant, fluoxetine (36 μg/l). Based on therapeutic use, these drugs may be most likely to enter the environment via the biomedical route (i.e. human excretion). To evaluate potential additive effects of similarly acting compounds, we performed bioassays with mixtures of 1-100 μg/l each of the antibiotics erythromycin, lincomycin, triclosan, trimethoprim, and sulfamethoxazole. Except for triclosan, all of these chemicals are antibiotics used in human and veterinary medicine and may enter the environment via the biomedical and/or agricultural routes; triclosan is an antimicrobial agent used in consumer products.

Based on therapeutic use, these drugs may be most likely to enter the environment via the biomedical route (i.e. human excretion). To evaluate potential additive effects of similarly acting compounds, we performed bioassays with mixtures of 1-100 μg/l each of the antibiotics erythromycin, lincomycin, triclosan, trimethoprim, and sulfamethoxazole. Except for triclosan, all of these chemicals are antibiotics used in human and veterinary medicine and may enter the environment via the biomedical and/or agricultural routes; triclosan is an antimicrobial agent used in consumer products.

Authors: Junghans, M; Backhaus, T; Faust, M; Scholze, M; Grimme, LH
Title: Predictability of combined effects of eight chloroacetanilide herbicides on algal reproduction
StressorOneNote: In this study, the individual and combined effects of 8 herbicides are tested. The response curves for each individual herbicide are measured and (so individual effects at all intensities can be estimated) and two mixtures are made using a fixed-ratio design.  Two different mixture ratios were tested: the eight chloroacetanilides were present either in the ratio of their individual EC50 values or in the ratio of their individual EC05 values (Table 2). Concentration-response analyses for both single substances and mixtures were performed in essentially the same way. Geometric dilution series were prepared from the aqueous stock solutions. To allow valid statistical estimations of concentration-response functions for the whole effect range, at least 12 different concentrations were tested with three replicates each and compared with 18 untreated controls. The spacing between the test concentrations was adapted to the steepness of the respective concentration-response relationship.

Title: Toxic effects of single animal hormones and their mixtures on the growth of Chlorella vulgaris and Scenedesmus armatus
StressorOneNote: Then microalgae cultures were cultivated in the presence of three contributions of hormones mixed in equal proportions: MIX1, which consisted of all of the studied hormones; MIX2, which consisted of the three hormones that proved to be most toxic, i.e. EE2, PRO, and TST; and MIX 3, which consisted of a combination of most toxic hormones with those that did not show significant effects, i.e. PRO, E1, E3, and LG. Stock solution of 10 g L-1 of each hormone was prepared in HPLC grade methanol and then the testing solutions were diluted to 0.1-100 mg L-1 concentration during the experiment. In order to achieve required MIX1, MIX2 and MIX3 concentration during the experiment 1/8, 1/3 and 1/4 of respective solution of each hormone (mg mL-1) was added to achieve the same concentration as for single hormones.

Stock solution of 10 g L-1 of each hormone was prepared in HPLC grade methanol and then the testing solutions were diluted to 0.1-100 mg L-1 concentration during the experiment. Authors: Lydy, MJ; Austin, KR
Title: Toxicity assessment of pesticide mixtures typical of the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta using Chironomus tentans
Source: ARCHIVES OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINATION AND TOXICOLOGY
StressorOneNote: Table 4 and 5 as details of all binary combinations. The measured toxicity of a mixture can be compared with the expected toxicity assuming strict additivity. If the 50% effect occurred at a TU <1, then the effects of the mixture were more than additive (synergistic). If the 50% effect = 1, the effects were additive. If the 50% effect occurred at a TU >1, the effects were less than additive (antagonistic). The concentrations of the combination of pesticides were equivalent to 0.50, 0.75, 1.0, 1.5, and 2.0 TU (see Pape-Lindstrom and Lydy 1997 for further details). The relationship between TU levels and binary mixture concentrations is presented in Table 2. Test results of individual pesticides and pesticide mixtures were analyzed using Probit procedure (SAS 1996) when criterion for parametric testing was met.

Authors: Lydy, MJ; Austin, KR
Title: Toxicity assessment of pesticide mixtures typical of the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta using Chironomus tentans
Source: ARCHIVES OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINATION AND TOXICOLOGY
StressorOneNote: Binary mixture testing was performed similar to the single-chemical bioassays using 96-hour intervals and fourth-instar C. tentans larvae. Two approaches were used to assess the joint toxicity of the binary mixtures. A toxic unit (TU) approach (Pape-Lindstrom and Lydy 1997) was used when the single-chemical tests indicated that both pesticides were toxic to C. tentans, and two-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) using Tukey's multiple comparisons (Belden and Lydy 2000) was used when one of the pesticides showed no toxicity in the single-chemical tests.

Authors: Fleming, CR; Di Giulio, RT
Title: The role of CYP1A inhibition in the embryotoxic interactions between hypoxia and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and PAH mixtures in zebrafish (Danio rerio)
StressorOneNote: Hypoxia exposures were performed in a Heraeus Heracell 150 Tri-Gas Cell Culture Incubator. Hypoxia exposures were performed at 7.4% oxygen (with ambient air assumed to be 21% oxygen); oxygen adjustment was accomplished by injection of nitrogen into the incubator and was regulated constantly throughout the 72 h exposure.
StressorTwoNote: BaP was used at final nominal concentrations of 100, 250 and 500 μg/l.  Additionally, two binary mixtures were tested: mixtures of BaP and AA with BaP at 250 μg/l and AA at 500 and 1,000 μg/l and mixtures of BaP and CB with BaP at 250 μg/l and CB at 500 and 1,000 μg/l. These mixtures were chosen because AhR agonist PAHs and CYP1A-inhibiting PAHs have been shown to exhibit synergistic embryotoxicity
StressorThreeNote: Final nominal concentrations of BkF were 1, 10, 100 and 200 μg/l.
StressorFourNote: The highest concentration of DBT that could be dissolved in DMSO was 10 mg/ml so the highest DBT concentration tested was limited by solubility and a desire to keep DMSO levels low and in keeping with our other experiments. Nominal concentrations of DBT used for dosing were 1,000 and 2,000 μg/L.
StressorFiveNote: 2-aminoanthracene was used at 500 μg/l and 1,000 μg/l. Additionally, two binary mixtures were tested: mixtures of BaP and AA with BaP at 250 μg/l and AA at 500 and 1,000 μg/l.
StressorSixNote: Carbazole was dosed at 500 and 1,000 μg/L. Additionally, two binary mixtures were tested: mixtures of BaP and CB with BaP at 250 μg/l and CB at 500 and 1,000 μg/l.
StressorSevenNote: Pyrene was dosed at 500 and 1,000 μg/L.
StressorEightNote: Nominal concentrations of Polychlorinated biphenyl 126 were 10, 100, 500, 1,000, 5,000, and 10,000 ng/L PCB-126
StressorNineNote: Coal Tar Extract (CT) was obtained from the Standard Reference Materials Program (SRM #1597a, NIST, Gaithersburg, MD). The original CT extract was prepared in toluene, so a dosing stock was made by evaporating the toluene and dissolving the extract in an equal volume of DMSO. Total PAH concentration in the extract was 4,363.83 mg/l. The coal tar extract was dosed at dilutions of 1, 5, 10, and 50 parts CT stock per million parts 30% Danieau, resulting in total PAH concentrations of 4, 22, 44, and 218 μg/l, respectively, based on the initial total PAH concentration of 4363.83 mg/l reported by NIST.

Authors: Minguez, L; Bureau, R; Halm-Lemeille, MP
Title: Joint effects of nine antidepressants on Raphidocelis subcapitata and Skeletonema marinoi: A matter of amine functional groups
StressorOneNote: the freshwater algae Raphidocelis subcapitata (formerly known as Pseudokirchneriella subcapitata) and the marine diatom Skeletonema marinoi were exposed to equitoxic mixtures of 9 antidepressants (fluvoxamine, fluoxetine, sertraline, duloxetine, venlafaxine, clomipramine, amitriptyline, and citalopram) at different concentrations to build response curves (in (μg/L) leading to 5, 10, 20, 50 and 80% of growth inhibition (ICx)). At least three technical replicates were used per concentration, and the exposure was repeated three times (i.e. biological replicates). The cell density was measured after 72 h of exposure. Tests were performed in 96-well cell culture plates, sealed with a polyester film to avoid evaporation and to isolate each well from the other.

Title: Interactive effects of metals in mixtures on bioaccumulation in the amphipod Hyalella azteca

Authors: Norwood, WP; Borgmann, U; Dixon, DG
Title: An effects addition model based on bioaccumulation of metals from exposure to mixtures of metals can predict chronic mortality in the aquatic invertebrate hyalella azteca
StressorOneNote: Chronic toxicity tests of mixtures of 9 metals and 1 metalloid (As, Cd, Co, Cr, Cu, Mn, Ni, Pb, Tl, and Zn) at equitoxic concentrations over an increasing concentration range were conducted. Each metal was spiked in an exponentially increasing equitoxic concentration series such that nominal concentrations of each metal were 0%, 5%, 7%, 10%, 16%, 25%, 39%, 61%, 100%, and 154% of their respective chronic 25% lethal concentration (LC25; Table 1). Not factorial. All 10 metals/metalloids individually and in one mixture. Levels estimated from figure 3.

Authors: Chamsi, O; Pinelli, E; Faucon, B; Perrault, A; Lacroix, L; Sanchez-Perez, JM; Charcosset, JY
Title: Effects of herbicide mixtures on freshwater microalgae with the potential effect of a safener
Source: ANNALES DE LIMNOLOGIE-INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF LIMNOLOGY
SingleSpecies: desmodesmus subspicatus; nitzschia palea; navicula pelliculosa
StressorOneNote: Eleven compounds were first tested singly and in a mixture (MixAll) on the three algae. In this mixture and the two others (Tab. 2), each agrochemical compound was tested at the concentration range indicated in Table 1. When tested singly, six compounds displayed an activity, of which five on D. subspicatus that include the two that were also active on N. palea. Two mixtures were then tested on the three species: (i) MixDs that comprises the compounds that displayed an effect on this species; (ii) MixDs without IODO (MixDsw/ oIODO), the compound that displayed the strongest effect. Then we tested the effect of the safener BE at two different concentrations that did not inhibit or stimulate the green alga growth.
